{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2013}} {{Year nav topic5|1935|radio|television|music|film}}
The year '''1935''' saw a number of significant happenings in '''[[radio broadcasting]]''' history.
==Events== *23 January – Station [[List of New Zealand radio station callsigns|1YA Auckland]] moves into the first purpose-built broadcasting premises in [[New Zealand]].<ref>[http://www.teara.govt.nz/en/1966/broadcasting-and-television/4 An Encyclopedia of New Zealand 1966]</ref> *25 January – [[Boris III of Bulgaria|Tsar Boris III]] signs a decree making all broadcasting in [[Bulgaria]] a state-organized activity. *17 February – The [[Droitwich transmitting station|Droitwich]] medium-wave transmitter begins service, broadcasting the [[BBC Regional Programme|Midland Regional Programme of the BBC]] on a frequency of 1013 kHz. *28 April – [[Fireside chats|Fireside chat]]: ''On the Works Relief Program'' *24 March – ''[[Major Bowes Amateur Hour]]'' is broadcast nationally for the first time on [[NBC]], after having been on the New York City radio station [[WEPN (AM)#WHN|WHN]]. *1 June – In Japan, [[NHK]] begins its international service, [[NHK#History|Radio Japan]], with a daily one-hour programme in English and Japanese beamed towards North America. *29 July – ''[[Lux Radio Theater]]'' has its first show on [[CBS]], after having been on [[NBC Blue]] for a year. *4 August – In [[Portugal]], the Emissora Nacional de Radiodifusão, forerunner of today's [[Rádio e Televisão de Portugal|RDP – Radiodifusão Portuguesa]], is officially inaugurated.
==Debuts==
===Programs=== *1 January – ''The Story of Mary Marlin'' debuts on [[NBC]] after having been on [[WMAQ (AM)|WMAQ]] in Chicago.<ref name="coxotd">Cox, Jim (2008). ''This Day in Network Radio: A Daily Calendar of Births, Debuts, Cancellations and Other Events in Broadcasting History''. McFarland & Company, Inc. {{ISBN|978-0-7864-3848-8}}.</ref> *4 January – [[Bob Hope]] has his network radio debut on the variety show ''[[The Intimate Revue]]''.<ref name=coxotd/> *4 January – ''The Beatrice Lillie Show'' debuts on [[NBC]].<ref name=dunningota/> *4 February – ''[[Mrs. Wiggs of the Cabbage Patch (radio)|Mrs. Wiggs of the Cabbage Patch]]'' debuts on [[CBS]]. *17 April – ''[[House of Glass (radio program)|House of Glass]]'' debuts on the Blue Network.<ref name=dunningota/> *20 April – ''[[Your Hit Parade]]'' (first known as just ''The Hit Parade'' or ''Lucky Strike Hit Parade'') debuts on [[NBC]]. *27 April – ''[[Flash Gordon]]'', a popular comic strip, debuts as a radio serial on the [[Mutual Broadcasting System]] *30 May – ''[[America's Town Meeting of the Air]]'' debuts on the [[Blue Network]].<ref name=dunningota/> *30 June – ''[[The Gibson Family#Uncle Charlie's Tent Show|Uncle Charlie's Tent Show]]''debuts on NBC.<ref name=dunningota/> *14 July – ''America's Hour'' debuts on [[CBS]].<ref name=dunningota/> *22 July – ''[[A Voz do Brasil]]'' debuts on Brazil's ''Programa Nacional'' (and will still be running more than 80 years later). *5 August – ''[[Backstage Wife]]'' debuts on [[Mutual Broadcasting System|Mutual]].<ref name="dunningota">Dunning, John. (1998). ''On the Air: The Encyclopedia of Old-Time Radio''. Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-507678-3}}.</ref> *9 October – ''[[Cavalcade of America]]'' debuts on [[CBS]].<ref name=dunningota/> *29 October – ''[[The Jumbo Fire Chief Program]]'' starring [[Jimmy Durante]] debuts on [[NBC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.digitaldeliftp.com/DigitalDeliToo/dd2jb-Jumbo-Fire-Chief-Program.html|title=The Jumbo Fire-Chief Program - The Digital Deli Online|publisher=www.digitaldeliftp.com|accessdate=10 May 2015}}</ref> *5 December – [[Bing Crosby]] becomes guest host of the ''[[Kraft Music Hall]]'' (and the following month becomes full-time host, after [[Paul Whiteman]]). *<small>UNDATED</small> – ''[[The Jack Berch Show]]'' debuts on the [[Blue Network]].<ref name=dunningota/>
===Stations=== *20 April – WLEU, Erie, Pennsylvania, begins broadcasting on 1420 kHz with 250 W power (daytime) and 100 W (night).<ref>{{cite news|title=WLEU Opens at Erie|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-BC/BC-1935/1935-05-01-BC.pdf|accessdate=24 October 2014|agency=Broadcasting|date=1 May 1935}}</ref> *1 October – KDON, Del Monte, California, begins broadcasting on 1210 kHz with 100 W power.<ref>{{cite news|title=New California Outlet|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-BC/BC-1935/1935-10-01-BC.pdf|accessdate=4 November 2014|agency=Broadcasting|date=1 October 1935}}</ref> *<small>UNDATED</small> – WTMV, East St. Louis, Illinois, begins broadcasting on 1500 kHz with 100 W power.<ref>{{cite news|title=WTMV, at East St. Louis, New 100-Watter, on Air|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-BC/BC-1935/1935-07-01-BC.pdf|accessdate=24 October 2014}}</ref>
==Endings== *2 April – KFPM, Greenville, Texas, ends broadcast operations. The station had 15 W power, and its operator said it was "losing money every day."<ref>{{cite news|title=15-Watter Gives Up|url=http://www.americanradiohistory.com/Archive-BC/BC-1935/1935-04-15-BC.pdf|accessdate=24 October 2014|agency=Broadcasting|date=15 April 1935}}</ref> *23 June – ''[[The Gibson Family]]'' ends its run on network radio (NBC).<ref name=dunningota/> *28 June – ''The Beatrice Lillie Show'' ends its run on network radio ([[NBC]]).<ref name=dunningota/> *8 September – ''[[The Gibson Family#Uncle Charlie's Tent Show|Uncle Charlie's Tent Show]]''ends its run on network radio (NBC).<ref name=dunningota/> *22 September – ''America's Hour'' ends its run on network radio ([[CBS]]).<ref name=dunningota/> *25 December – ''House of Glass'' ends its run on the Blue Network.<ref name=dunningota/>
==Births== *18 December – [[Rosemary Leach]] (died 2017), English actress. *[[Gary Dee]] (died 1995), pioneer in controversial [[talk radio]], mostly in [[Cleveland, Ohio]].
==References== {{reflist}}
[[Category:1935 in radio|1935 in radio]] [[Category:Years in radio]]

{{Year nav topic5|1955|radio|television|music|film}} The year '''1955''' saw a number of significant events in '''[[radio broadcasting]]''' history.
==Events== *2 May – Opening at [[Wrotham transmitting station|Wrotham]], [[Kent]], of the [[United Kingdom]]'s first [[Very high frequency|VHF]]/[[Frequency modulation|FM]] transmitters. *22 September – The character [[Grace Archer]] dies in the [[BBC]] radio serial ''[[The Archers]]''; a spoiler for the launch of [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] in the UK on the same day.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/radio4/archers/timeline/timeline_50s.shtml BBC: The Archers, timeline.]</ref> *20 October – [[Disc jockey]] [[Bill Randle]] of [[WERE]] ([[Cleveland]]) is the key presenter of a concert at [[Brooklyn High School (Ohio)]], featuring [[Pat Boone]] and [[Bill Haley & His Comets]] and opening with [[Elvis Presley]], not only Elvis's first performance north of the [[Mason–Dixon line]], but also his first filmed performance, for a documentary on Randle titled ''[[The Pied Piper of Cleveland]]''. *17 November – Creation of the ''Communauté des radios publiques de langue française'' (CRPLF) - an association of the French-language public broadcasters of [[France]], [[Switzerland]], [[Belgium]], and [[Canada]], later to become, in 2002, the ''[[Public Francophone Radios|Radios francophones publiques]]'' (RFP). *26 November – In [[Sweden]], the national public broadcaster Radiotjänst (modern-day [[Sveriges Radio]]) begins transmission, via [[FM broadcasting|FM]], of its [[Sveriges Radio P2|second radio channel]] in [[Stockholm]], [[Gothenburg]], [[Malmö]], and [[Örebro]].
==Debuts== *June 12 – ''[[Monitor (NBC Radio)|Monitor]]'' debuts<ref name="coxotd">Cox, Jim (2008). ''This Day in Network Radio: A Daily Calendar of Births, Debuts, Cancellations and Other Events in Broadcasting History''. McFarland & Company, Inc. {{ISBN|978-0-7864-3848-8}}.</ref> on [[NBC Red Network|NBC Radio]]. *August 8 – [[WPLM (AM)|WPLM]]/1390 signs on.
==Closings== *March 10 – ''[[The Silver Eagle]]'' broadcasts its last episode. *March 23 – ''[[The Big Story (radio/TV)|The Big Story]]'' ends its run on [[NBC]].<ref name=dunningota/> *March 27 - ''[[Hallmark Playhouse#Hallmark Hall of Fame|Hallmark Hall of Fame]]'' ends its run on network radio ([[CBS]]).<ref name=dunningota/> *May 22 – ''[[The Jack Benny Program]]'' airs its last radio episode and moves solely to television. *June 7 – ''[[Lux Radio Theatre|Lux Radio Theater]]'' ends its run on [[CBS]]. *June 9 - ''[[Challenge of the Yukon|Sergeant Preston of the Yukon]]'' ends its run on network radio ([[Mutual Broadcasting System|Mutual]]).<ref name=dunningota/> *June 30 - ''[[Barrie Craig, Confidential Investigator]]'' ends its run on network radio ([[NBC]]).<ref name="dunningota">Dunning, John. (1998). ''On the Air: The Encyclopedia of Old-Time Radio''. Oxford University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-19-507678-3}}.</ref> *July 1 - ''[[Joyce Jordan, M.D.]]'' ends its run on network radio. ([[NBC]])<ref name=dunningota/> *July 15 - ''[[Break the Bank (1948 game show)|Break the Bank]]'' ends its run on network radio ([[NBC]]).<ref name=dunningota/> *October 13 - ''[[Dr. Sixgun]]'' ends its run on network radio ([[NBC]]).<ref name=dunningota/>
==Births== *February 10 – [[Jim Cramer]], [[Americans|American]] television personality, former [[hedge fund]] manager and best-selling author. *February 23 – [[Tom Bodett]], American author, voice actor, radio host and spokesman for the hotel chain [[Motel 6]]. *April 5 – [[Janice Long]], born Janice Chegwin, [[English people|English]] disc jockey. *October 4 – [[Dale Connelly]], American co-host (with [[Tom Keith]], a.k.a. Jim Ed Poole) of [[The Morning Show (Minnesota Public Radio)|''The Morning Show'']] on [[Minnesota Public Radio]]. *Approximate date – [[Christopher Douglas (British actor)|Christopher Douglas]], English comedy actor-writer.
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} [[File:2011TsunamiFireVehicles.jpg|thumb|A convoy of fire engines in the tsunami zone]]
The '''aftermath of the [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]]''' included both a humanitarian crisis and massive economic impacts. The [[tsunami]] created over 300,000 refugees in the [[Tōhoku region]] of [[Japan]], and resulted in shortages of food, water, shelter, medicine and fuel for survivors. 15,891 deaths have been confirmed. In response to the crisis, the Japanese government mobilized the [[Japan Self-Defense Forces|Self-Defence Forces]], while many countries sent search and rescue teams to help search for survivors. Aid organizations both in Japan and worldwide also responded, with the [[Japanese Red Cross]] reporting $1 billion in donations. The economic impact included both immediate problems, with industrial production suspended in many factories, and the longer term issue of the cost of rebuilding which has been estimated at ¥10 trillion ($122 billion).
A further serious impact of the tsunami was the critical damage done to the [[Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant]], resulting in [[Fukushima I nuclear incidents|severe releases of radioactivity]] and the prospect of a long-term health and [[environmental hazard]] in need of an expensive cleanup.
==Humanitarian crisis== [[File:Temporary housings for tsunami evacuees in Shichigahama.jpg|thumb|Emergency housing under construction in Shichigahama]]
The [[2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami]] caused a large number of displaced people. The number of evacuees, as of 26 January 2012, was 341,411.<ref>[[Jiji Press]], "11 March death toll updated to 15,848", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 12 February 2012, p. 1.</ref> Some earthquake survivors died in shelters or in the process of evacuation. Many shelters struggled to feed evacuees and were not sufficiently equipped medically.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.asahi.com/national/update/0317/TKY201103170134.html |title=asahi.com（朝日新聞社）：避難所など震災関連死２７人 医療設備不足や寒さ響く – 社会 |work=Asahi Shimbun |location=Japan |date=17 March 2011 |accessdate=29 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110331005043/http://www.asahi.com/national/update/0317/TKY201103170134.html| archivedate= 31 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Fujimura |first=Naoko |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-26/japan-s-evacuees-battle-flu-survive-on-rice-balls-and-bread.html |title=Quake Evacuees Survive on Rice Balls, Bread, Seek to Avoid Contracting Flu |publisher=Bloomberg |date= 26 March 2011|accessdate=29 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110331005142/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-26/japan-s-evacuees-battle-flu-survive-on-rice-balls-and-bread.html| archivedate= 31 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Fuel shortages hampered relief actions. In the first week after the earthquake, supplies of food, water, and medicine were held up due to a fuel shortage and weather conditions.<ref>[http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/83d55156-509a-11e0-9e89-00144feab49a.html#axzz1I363qFis / Asia-Pacific – Fuel shortages hamper humanitarian effort]. Ft.com (2011-03-17). Retrieved on 1 April 2011.</ref> Food was limited for some unevacuated people, and as of late March, some were given one meal a day.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fackler |first=Martin |title=In Japanese Whaling Town, Food Is Rationed but Resolve Is Plentiful |work=The New York Times |date=29 March 2011 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/29/world/asia/29endure.html}}</ref>
There is a need for temporary housing, as the Japanese government are trying to remove evacuees from large shelters, where there have been reports of poor sanitary conditions. As of late March, 8,800 temporary units were planned in Iwate, 10,000 in Miyagi, and 19,000 in Fukushima.<ref>Fujimura, Naoko. (2011-03-28) [https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-28/japan-starts-to-rebuild-after-quake-as-evacuees-told-to-avoid-power-plant.html Japan Moves to Relocate Quake Victims After Meeting Food, Clothing Targets]. Bloomberg. Retrieved on 1 April 2011.</ref>
At the end of July 2011, the number of evacuees in Japan stood at 87,063. Of those, 12,905 were residing in public shelters and 19,918 were staying in inns or hotels. 46,081 units of temporary housing, about 88 percent of the number planned, had been erected. Evacuees had moved into 73 percent of the temporary housing available.<ref name="search.japantimes.co.jp">[[Kyodo News]], "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110811x1.html 87,000 still in limbo five months after quake]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 12 August 2011, p. 1.</ref>
==Nuclear accidents== {{main|Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster}} [[File:Fukushima I by Digital Globe crop.jpg|thumb|The 2011 [[Fukushima Daiichi nuclear disaster]], the worst [[nuclear accident]] in 25 years, displaced 50 000 households after [[radioactivity|radioactive material]] leaked into the air, soil and sea.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-06-26/fukushima-retiree-to-lead-anti-nuclear-motion.html |title=Fukushima Retiree Leads Anti-Nuclear Shareholders at Tepco Annual Meeting |author=Tomoko Yamazaki and Shunichi Ozasa |date=27 June 2011 |work=Bloomberg }}</ref>]]
Following the earthquake, tsunami, and failure of cooling systems at [[Fukushima I Nuclear Power Plant]] and [[2011 Japanese nuclear incidents|issues concerning other nuclear facilities]] in Japan on 11 March 2011, a nuclear emergency was declared. This was the first time a nuclear emergency had been declared in Japan, and 140,000 residents within {{convert|20|km|0|abbr=on}} of the plant were evacuated.<ref name="bi-emergency">{{cite news|last=Weisenthal|first=Joe|title=Japan Declares Nuclear Emergency, As Cooling System Fails At Power Plant|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/fukushima-nuclear-plant-2011-3|accessdate=11 March 2011|newspaper=Business Insider|date=11 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110311152117/http://www.businessinsider.com/fukushima-nuclear-plant-2011-3| archivedate= 11 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Explosions and a fire have resulted in dangerous levels of [[radiation]], sparking a stock market collapse and panic-buying in supermarkets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1500862/Blasts-escalate-Japan's-nuclear-crisis |title=Blasts escalate Japan's nuclear crisis |date=16 March 2011 |work=World News Australia |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110407005125/http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/1500862/Blasts-escalate-Japan%27s-nuclear-crisis |archivedate=7 April 2011 |df= }}</ref> The UK, France and some other countries advised their nationals to consider leaving Tokyo, in response to fears of spreading nuclear contamination. The accidents have drawn attention to ongoing concerns over [[Nuclear power in Japan#Seismicity|Japanese nuclear seismic design standards]] and caused other governments to [[International reaction to Fukushima I nuclear accidents#Re-evaluation of existing nuclear energy programs|re-evaluate their nuclear programs]]. As of April 2011, water is still being poured into the damaged reactors to cool melting fuel rods. John Price, a former member of the Safety Policy Unit at the UK's National Nuclear Corporation, has said that it "might be 100 years before melting fuel rods can be safely removed from Japan's Fukushima nuclear plant".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/04/01/3179487.htm |title=Crews 'facing 100-year battle' at Fukushima |author=David Mark, Mark Willacy |date=1 April 2011 |work=ABC News }}</ref>
Problems in stabilizing the Fukushima I plant have hardened attitudes to [[nuclear power]]. As of June 2011, "more than 80 percent of Japanese now say they are [[anti-nuclear]] and distrust government information on [[radiation]]".<ref name=refuse2011/> The ongoing Fukushima crisis may spell the end of nuclear power in Japan, as "citizen opposition grows and local authorities refuse permission to restart reactors that have undergone safety checks". Local authorities are skeptical that sufficient safety measures have been taken and are reticent to give their permission – now required by law – to bring suspended nuclear reactors back online.<ref name=refuse2011>{{cite web |url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Asia-Pacific/2011/0620/Beginning-of-the-end-for-nuclear-power-in-Japan |title=Beginning of the end for nuclear power in Japan? |author=Gavin Blair, |date=20 June 2011 |work=CSMonitor }}</ref>
==Economic impact==
===Japan=== [[File:Queue to Seven-eleven at 2011 Sendai earthquake.jpg|thumb|Shoppers line up to buy supplies after the earthquake]]
Following the earthquake some analysts were predicting that the total recovery costs could reach ¥10 trillion ($122 billion);<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/japan-looks-for-market-stability-after-quake-2240323.html|title=Japan looks for market stability after quake|work=The Independent |date=13 March 2011|accessdate=13 March 2011|first=Margareta|last=Pagano|location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002509/http://www.independent.co.uk/news/business/news/japan-looks-for-market-stability-after-quake-2240323.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> however, by 12 April 2011 the Japanese government estimated that the cost of just the direct material damage could exceed ¥25 trillion ($300 billion).<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/12/japan-economy-idUSL3E7FC09220110412 WRAPUP 2-Japan quake's economic impact worse than first feared] [[Reuters]], published 2011-04-12, accessed 14 April 2011</ref> Japan's real gross domestic product contracted 3.7% for the quarter of January to March 2011.<ref>[[Associated Press]], "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nb20110520n1.html Economy slides back into recession]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 20 May 2011, p. 1.</ref>
The northern Tōhoku region, which was most affected, accounts for about 8% of the country's gross domestic product, with factories that manufacture products such as cars and beer, as well as energy infrastructure.<ref name="bloombergspendingplan" /> It includes northern Miyagi prefecture, where Sendai is, about {{convert|300|km|mi|abbr=on}} northeast of Tokyo. The Miyagi area includes manufacturing and industrial zones with chemical and electronics plants. It is estimated that Miyagi accounts for 1.7% of Japan's gross domestic product.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.financialpost.com/news/pledges+support+Toyota+halts+output/4426436/story.html |title=BoJ pledges support; Toyota halts output |date=11 March 2011 |author=Osamu Tsukimori and Stanley White |publisher=Reuters via Financial Post}}</ref>
An estimated 23,600 hectares of farmland, mostly rice paddies, were damaged by the tsunami. Salt left in the soil by the seawater could adversely affect rice crops for years. The affected area accounts for as much as 3%–4% of Japan's rice production.<ref>Martin, Alex, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110408f2.html Farmers struggle amid tsunami aftermath]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 8 April 2011, p. 3.</ref> An estimated 4.37 million chickens in northeast Japan died following the earthquake as a result of disruptions in the supply of feed from overseas suppliers.<ref name="Metropolis 2012, p. 4">''[[Metropolis (free magazine)|Metropolis]]'', "The Small Print", 16–29 March 2012, No. 938, p. 4.</ref>
An estimated 90% of the 29,000 fishing boats in Miyagi, Iwate, and Fukushima prefectures were rendered unusable by the tsunami.<ref>[[Kyodo News]], "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110428a5.html 90% of Tohoku's fishing fleet said lost]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 28 April 2011, p. 2.</ref> Miyagi Prefecture's fishing industry was almost completely destroyed. Twelve thousand of 13,000 registered fishing boats in the prefecture were destroyed or damaged. At least 440 fishermen were killed or missing. The damage to the prefecture's fishing industry was estimated at ¥400 billion (US$5 billion).<ref>Robson, Seth, and Elena Sugiyama, "[http://www.stripes.com/news/pacific/earthquake-disaster-in-japan/miyagi-prefecture-fishing-industry-devastated-by-tsunami-1.141489 Miyagi prefecture fishing industry devastated by tsunami]", ''[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]'', 20 April 2011.</ref> The total damage to Japan's fishing industry, in seven affected prefectures, was estimated at ¥1.26 trillion (US$11.29 billion).<ref>Kamiya, Setsuko, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120307f1.html Fisheries rebound at sporadic pace]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 7 March 2012, p. 1.</ref>
The earthquake and tsunami have had significant immediate impacts on businesses such as [[Toyota]], [[Nissan]] and [[Honda]], which completely suspended auto production until 14 March 2011. [[Nippon Steel Corporation]] also suspended production, [[Toyo Tire & Rubber Company]] and [[Sumitomo Rubber Industries]] shuttered their tire and rubber production lines, while [[GS Yuasa]] closed its [[automotive battery]] production. This was expected to hinder supply availability for automakers.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/business/news/20110313p2g00m0bu012000c.html |title=Toyota, other automakers to suspend production at all domestic plants |date=13 March 2011 |work=Mainichi Daily News |accessdate=13 March 2011 |location=Tokyo |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5x9RsDbNC?url=http://mdn.mainichi.jp/mdnnews/business/news/20110313p2g00m0bu012000c.html |archivedate=13 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
[[Tokyo Electric Power Company]], [[Toshiba]], [[East Japan Railway Company]] and [[Shin-Etsu Chemical]] were suggested as the most vulnerable companies as a result of the earthquake.<ref>{{cite news|last=Fujimura |first=Naoko |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-13/tokyo-electric-toshiba-east-japan-rail-may-be-among-most-hurt-by-quake.html |title=Tokyo Electric, Toshiba, East Japan Rail May Be Among Most Hurt by Quake |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=13 March 2011 |date=13 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002523/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-13/tokyo-electric-toshiba-east-japan-rail-may-be-among-most-hurt-by-quake.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[Sony]] also suspended production at all its six plants in the area, while [[Fuji Heavy Industries]] discontinued production at most of its factories in the [[Gunma]] and the [[Tochigi Prefecture]]s.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Knight |first=Ben |url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,14908442,00.html |title=Japan's monster quake cripples industry, strains economic recovery |date=13 March 2011 |work=[[Deutsche Welle]] |agency=Reuters; [[Agence France-Presse]] |accessdate=13 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002519/http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0%2C%2C14908442%2C00.html |archivedate=16 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Other factories suspending operations include [[Kirin Company|Kirin Holdings]], [[GlaxoSmithKline]], [[Nestlé]]<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/13/japan-economy-recession-earthquake-tsunami |title=Japan's economy heads into freefall after earthquake and tsunami |last=Webb |first=Tim |date=13 March 2011 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=13 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xA7Gsz2R?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/13/japan-economy-recession-earthquake-tsunami |archivedate=13 March 2011 |location=London |deadurl=no Toyota expected some shutdowns in North America, but these would be temporary since many needed parts were shipped before the earthquake.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.thesunnews.com/2011/03/25/2060034/quake-idles-engine-plant.html|title=Quake idles engine plant in Japan|last=Durbin|first=Dee-Ann|work=[[The Sun News]]|agency=[[Associated Press]]|date=25 March 2011|accessdate=25 March 2011|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110331005116/http://www.thesunnews.com/2011/03/25/2060034/quake-idles-engine-plant.html|archivedate=31 March 2011|deadurl=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref><ref>Carty, Sharon Silke, and Elaine Kurtenbach, ([[Associated Press]]), "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nb20110329a1.html Tohoku disaster may bring automakers to their knees]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 29 March 2011, p. 8.</ref>
[[File:Shops in Tokyo empty shelves.jpg|thumb|left|Some items sell out at a Tokyo store]]
Chief economist for Japan at Credit Suisse, Hiromichi Shirakawa, said in a note to clients that the estimated economic loss may be around $171 billion–$183 billion just to the region hit by the quake and tsunami. On 14 March, the [[Bank of Japan]], in an attempt to maintain market stability,<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/14/us-japan-economy-boj-idUSTRE72D02J20110314|title=BOJ offers record 7 trillion yen to soothe markets |last=Kihara|first=Leika|first2=Rie|last2=Ishiguro|date=14 March 2011|agency=Reuters |accessdate=14 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002538/https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/14/us-japan-economy-boj-idUSTRE72D02J20110314| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/mar/14/bank-of-japan-pumps-billions-markets |title=Bank of Japan pumps billions into financial markets |last=Wearden |first=Graeme |date=14 March 2011 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=15 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xDFjXIOU?url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/business/2011/mar/14/bank-of-japan-pumps-billions-markets/print |archivedate=15 March 2011 |location=London |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> injected 15 trillion yen into the [[money market]]s to assure financial stability amid a plunge in stocks and surge in credit risk. After it set up an emergency task force to ensure [[liquidity]] in the aftermath of the disaster, governor [[Masaaki Shirakawa]] and the bank's board also enlarged a programme to buy government bonds to exchange-traded funds to the tune of 10 trillion yen. The BOJ chief told reporters cash injections will continue as needed.<ref>{{Cite news|title=BOJ Pledges Support on Japan Earthquake; Toyota Halts Output |author=Christopher Anstey and Mayumi Otsuma |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-11/kan-mobilizes-forces-central-bank-pledges-liquidity-after-japanese-quake.html |newspaper=[[Bloomberg News]] |date=11 March 2011 |accessdate=12 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002531/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-11/kan-mobilizes-forces-central-bank-pledges-liquidity-after-japanese-quake.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> However, following the further nuclear leaks, its actions were read by the market as insufficient<ref>{{cite news|last=Ujikane |first=Keiko |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-15/bank-of-japan-fails-to-contain-investor-panic-as-nuclear-danger-escalates.html |title=Bank of Japan Fails to Contain Investor Panic as Nuclear Danger Escalates – Bloomberg |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=15 March 2011 |date=15 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002537/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-15/bank-of-japan-fails-to-contain-investor-panic-as-nuclear-danger-escalates.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> despite 8 trillion yen being pumped into the market.<ref>{{cite news|last=Funabiki |first=Saburo |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-14/bank-of-japan-adds-86-billion-to-help-stabilize-markets-after-earthquake.html |title=Bank of Japan Adds 8 Trillion Yen Through 1-Day Operations – Bloomberg |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=15 March 2011 |date=15 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002540/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-14/bank-of-japan-adds-86-billion-to-help-stabilize-markets-after-earthquake.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> On 15 March, the [[Topix]] index fell again marking a two-day plunge not seen since 1987 as Japan's default risk surged after Prime Minister Naoto Kan warned of further leaks from the damaged nuclear power plant. Commodities were also significantly lower.<ref>{{cite news|last=Armstrong |first=Paul |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-15/nikkei-225-set-for-worst-two-day-slump-since-2008-yen-weakens-after-quake.html |title=Stocks, Commodities Fall Amid Japan Disaster; Treasuries Up – Bloomberg |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=15 March 2011 |date=15 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002545/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-15/nikkei-225-set-for-worst-two-day-slump-since-2008-yen-weakens-after-quake.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Residents of Tokyo were reported to have gone on panic shopping sprees as daily necessities were sought after and gasoline was stocked up with the increasing risk of radioactivity releases.<ref>{{cite news|last=Ozasa |first=Shunichi |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-15/japanese-consumers-empty-supermarket-shelves-as-soon-as-supplies-arrive.html |title=Tokyo Shoppers Strip Stores as Nuclear Risk Sparks Panic – Bloomberg |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=15 March 2011 |date=15 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002548/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-15/japanese-consumers-empty-supermarket-shelves-as-soon-as-supplies-arrive.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[Chief Cabinet Secretary]] [[Yukio Edano]] said that Japan's government will convene on 13 March to gauge the economic effects of the catastrophe.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jsV8XkEX5GVEjzyQE_qZfJ7mBU1A?docId=CNG.c24b36c3fa9ebaf6a82bf3e95df9eca3.a1 |title=Japan says quake impact on economy 'considerable' |date=13 March 2011 |agency=Agence France-Presse |accessdate=13 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5x9QWwOTi?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jsV8XkEX5GVEjzyQE_qZfJ7mBU1A?docId=CNG.c24b36c3fa9ebaf6a82bf3e95df9eca3.a1 |archivedate=13 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> He told NHK Television that about 200 billion yen that was remaining from the budget for the concurrent fiscal year that would end on 31 March would be used to fund the immediate recovery efforts. Additional measures could also hurt Japan's [[public debt]] (which is already the highest in the world). This additional spending could hurt demand for government bonds.<ref name="bloombergspendingplan">{{cite news|last=Anstey |first=Christopher |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-12/japan-faces-another-leg-down-in-its-fiscal-health-after-quake.html |title=Japan Plans Spending Package as Quake Slams World's Most Indebted Economy |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=13 March 2011 |date=13 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002513/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-12/japan-faces-another-leg-down-in-its-fiscal-health-after-quake.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[Silicon wafer]] production has been suspended at factories owned by [[Shin-Etsu Chemical]] and [[MEMC Electronic Materials]], which together account for 25% of the global silicon wafer production. The suspension is expected to drastically impact semiconductor production, which is contingent on wafer availability.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110321-709860.html|title=Japan Quake Has Stopped About 25% Of Silicon-Wafer Production -IHS iSuppli|last=Becker|first=Nathan|date=21 March 2011|work=The Wall Street Journal|accessdate=21 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110321213550/http://online.wsj.com/article/BT-CO-20110321-709860.html| archivedate= 21 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-21/japan-earthquake-suspends-25-of-world-silicon-isuppli-says-1-.html |title=Japan Earthquake Suspends 25% of World Silicon, ISuppli Says |last=King |first=Ian |date=21 March 2011 |work=[[Bloomberg News]] |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xMIpsnsJ?url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-21/japan-earthquake-suspends-25-of-world-silicon-isuppli-says-1-.html |archivedate=21 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
Some economic analysts consider that, ultimately, the catastrophe will improve Japan's economy, with increased job availability during restoration efforts. An analyst at [[JPMorgan Chase]], citing the [[1989 Loma Prieta earthquake]] in the [[San Francisco Bay Area]] and the Southern California [[1994 Northridge earthquake]], noted that natural disasters "do eventually boost output." An analyst at [[Société Générale]] anticipated that Japan's economy will decline in March 2011 but will revive powerfully in subsequent months. After the [[Great Hanshin earthquake|Kobe earthquake]], industrial output dropped 2.6%, but increased by 2.2% the next month and 1% the following month. Japan's economy then accelerated substantially through the next two years, at more than its former rate.<ref name="economicrecovery" /> Others are of the opinion that the catastrophe will harm the economy.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.pbs.org/nbr/blog/2011/03/japan_tsunami_economy.html |title=Japan's Tsunami- The Broken Window Fallacy Returns | XChange – The NBR Blog | Nightly Business Report |publisher=PBS |accessdate=13 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002510/http://www.pbs.org/nbr/blog/2011/03/japan_tsunami_economy.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Some analysts have argued that those who predict that the reconstruction effort could help Japan's economy have fallen prey to the [[broken window fallacy]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Melloan |first=George |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748704893604576200670789813058?mod=rss_opinion_main |title=''Japan and the Broken Window Fallacy'', George Melloan, March 15, 2011, Wall Street Journal |work=The Wall Street Journal |date= 15 March 2011|accessdate=15 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110315182606/http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704893604576200670789813058.html?mod=rss_opinion_main| archivedate= 15 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> On 24 March, an executive of Bank of Japan's [[Osaka]] branch said he expected "a big decline in production, [leading to] an adjustment in the economy initially with exports and inventories falling and imports rising... Demand created by reconstruction projects will emerge after that." The government said that reconstruction in the ongoing year could raise GDP by 5 trillion yen to 7.75 trillion yen.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-24/earthquake-rebuilding-effort-will-outweigh-japan-slump-boj-official-says.html |title=Earthquake Rebuilding Effort Will Outweigh Japan Slump, BOJ Official Says |last=Otsuma |first=Mayumi |first2=Masahiro |last2=Hidaka |date=24 March 2011 |work=[[Bloomberg News]] |accessdate=24 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xQuHNCeD?url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-24/earthquake-rebuilding-effort-will-outweigh-japan-slump-boj-official-says.html |archivedate=24 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
By the end of July 2011, 47 percent of the 22.63 million tons of debris in Iwate, Miyagi, and Fukushima Prefectures had been removed.<ref name="search.japantimes.co.jp"/> By 11 July 2011, 73.7% of farming businesses affected by the quake and tsunami in eight prefectures had resumed operations while 35.5% of fishing entities had returned to business, according to the Japanese agricultural ministry. The ministry excluded Fukushima from the results because of the ongoing nuclear crisis.<ref>[[Kyodo News]], "Farm industry coming back", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 24 September 2011, p. 2.</ref>
The reconstruction of damaged areas in Tōhoku beginning in 2011 produced a boom in construction jobs and business in the area. As a result, cities like Sendai benefited from an increase in residents and wages for construction-related jobs rose.<ref>Johnston, Eric, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20120327i1.html Tohoku in rebuilding bubble]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 27 March 2012, p. 3.</ref>
By March 2012, 644 companies in Japan had been forced into bankruptcy by the disaster. The companies included 157 service companies, 150 manufacturers, and 113 wholesalers. The companies left behind liabilities of ¥925.4 billion (US$8 billion) and had employed 11,412 people.<ref>[[Kyodo News]], "March disasters caused 644 firms in 40 prefectures to go bankrupt", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 11 March 2012, p. 1.</ref>
===Global financial impact=== In the immediate aftermath of the earthquake, Japan's ''[[Nikkei 225|Nikkei]]'' stock market index saw its futures slide 5% in after-market trading.<ref name="Reuters">{{cite news|author=Reuters 10:05 am GMT 11 March 2011 Comments |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/markets/8375674/Japan-earthquake-market-reaction.html |title=Japan earthquake: market reaction |publisher=Telegraph |date= 11 March 2011|accessdate=11 March 2011 |location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002527/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/markets/8375674/Japan-earthquake-market-reaction.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The [[Bank of Japan]] said that it would do its utmost to ensure financial market stability.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marketwatch.com/story/boj-to-work-to-ensure-financial-market-stability-2011-03-11|title=BOJ to Work to Ensure Financial Market Stability|date=11 March 2011}}</ref> On Tuesday, 15 March, news of rising radiation levels caused the ''Nikkei'' to drop over 1,000 points or 10.6% (16% for the week).<ref>{{cite web|title=Treasurys Surge Following Nikkei Plunge|url=https://www.cnbc.com/id/42085204|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=14 March 2011|date=15 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002523/http://www.cnbc.com/id/42085204| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Other stock markets around the world were also affected; the German [[DAX]] lost 1.2% within minutes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.zeit.de/gesellschaft/zeitgeschehen/2011-03/japan-erdbeben-tsunami|title=Erdbeben Japan: Riesige Flutwelle spült Trümmer übers Land|date=11 March 2011|accessdate=11 March 2011|language=German|work=[[Die Zeit]]| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002510/http://www.zeit.de/gesellschaft/zeitgeschehen/2011-03/japan-erdbeben-tsunami| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Hong Kong's Hang Seng index fell by 1.8%, while South Korea's Kospi index slumped by 1.3%.<ref>{{Cite |accessdate=12 March 2011 |location=London| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002533/http://www.telegraph.co.uk/finance/markets/8376330/Japan-earthquake-hits-global-markets.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> By the end of trading on the day of the earthquake, the MSCI Asia Pacific Index had dropped by 1.8%.<ref>{{Cite <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Major U.S. stock market indexes rose between 0.5% and 0.7%.<ref>{{Cite news |title=Stocks rebound after Japan earthquake |first=Shanthi |last=Bharatwaj |url= http://www.thestreet.com/_yahoo/story/11040546/1/stock-market-story-march-11.html?cm_ven=YAHOO&cm_cat=FREE&cm_ite=NA |newspaper=The Street |date=11 March 2011 |accessdate=12 March 2011}}</ref> Oil prices also dropped as a result of the closure of Japanese refineries, despite the [[2011 Libyan civil war|ongoing violence in Libya]] and expected [[2011 Saudi Arabian protests|demonstrations in Saudi Arabia]]. [[West Texas Intermediate|US crude]] dropped as low as US$99.01 from $100.08 by lunchtime, with [[Brent Crude]] falling $2.62 to $112.81.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0311/oil-business.html|title=Oil prices drop after Japan quake|publisher=Raidió Teilifís Éireann|date=11 March 2011|accessdate=11 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002510/http://www.rte.ie/news/2011/0311/oil-business.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> In Hong Kong, Financial Secretary [[John Tsang]] warned investors to "take extra care" as the earthquake may have a short-term impact on local stock markets.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rthk.hk/rthk/news/elocal/news.htm?elocal&20110312&56&740229|title=FS warns of quake impact on shares|publisher=RTHK|date=12 March 2011|accessdate=12 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002511/http://rthk.hk/rthk/news/elocal/news.htm?elocal&20110312&56&740229| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
[[File:OshimaFieldShower2011.jpg|thumb|left|Water shortages are severe enough to require the construction of temporary shower facilities in some locations]]
The share prices of the biggest [[reinsurance]] companies [[Munich Re]] and [[Swiss Reinsurance Company]] fell following the earthquake on speculation that they may face losses "somewhere in the $10 billion range" even after certain costs were absorbed by Japan's primary insurers and the government.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kucera |first=Danielle |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-11/european-reinsurers-fall-leading-u-s-carriers-lower-on-quake.html |title=Reinsurers Decline as Japan Quake, Tsunami May Cause $10 Billion in Claims |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=12 March 2011 |date=11 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002554/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-11/european-reinsurers-fall-leading-u-s-carriers-lower-on-quake.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
The [[Japanese yen]] soared against most major currencies following the earthquake and reached a post-World War II high of 76.25 yen to the US dollar on speculation that Japanese investors would repatriate assets to pay for rebuilding.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-12768098|title=Yen hits record-high against US dollar as Nikkei falls|work=BBC|accessdate=21 March 2011|date=17 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110318065241/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/business-12768098| archivedate= 18 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Since Japan relies heavily on exports, the strong yen could dampen its economy further. The financial markets' instability prompted the [[G7]] to meet on 17 March, resulting in an agreement on joint [[Economic interventionism|forex intervention]] to sell yen against the dollar;<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-19/yen-decline-after-g-7-s-post-earthquake-intervention-pares-gain.html|title=Yen Declines After G-7’s Post-Earthquake Market Intervention Pares Gain|publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=21 March 2011|first1=Catarina|last1=Saraiva|first2=Charles|last2=Mead|date=19 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110320213131/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-19/yen-decline-after-g-7-s-post-earthquake-intervention-pares-gain.html| archivedate= 20 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> it was the first such move since 2000.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://in.reuters.com/article/2011/03/18/idINIndia-55675620110318|title=G7 agrees joint intervention to curb strong yen|work=Reuters|accessdate=21 March 2011|date=18 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110324003320/http://in.reuters.com/article/2011/03/18/idINIndia-55675620110318| archivedate= 24 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Peter Bradford, a former member of the United States' [[Nuclear Regulatory Commission]], said that the impact on the nuclear power plant was "obviously a significant setback for the so-called [[nuclear renaissance]]. The image of a nuclear power plant blowing up before your eyes on a television screen is a first."<ref>{{cite news|last=Polson |first=Jim |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-13/nuclear-renaissance-threatened-as-japanese-reactor-struggles-after-quake.html |title=Nuclear Renaissance Threatened as Japan Fights Meltdown at Quake-Hit Plant |publisher=Bloomberg |accessdate=13 March 2011 |date=13 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002601/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-13/nuclear-renaissance-threatened-as-japanese-reactor-struggles-after-quake.html| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Response in Japan==
===Government=== [[File:PM Kan visits JSDF and service members at Ishanomaki High School Image 2 of 6.jpg|thumb|On 11 April, Prime Minister Naoto Kan was briefed about the state of Ishinomaki Commercial High School in [[Ishinomaki, Miyagi]] by Lt. Gen. Yuji Kuno, the Commander of the 6th Division of the [[Japan Ground Self-Defense Force]]]]
Then Prime Minister [[Naoto Kan]] announced that the government had mobilized the [[Japan Self-Defense Forces]] in earthquake disaster zones.<ref name="bl" /> He asked the Japanese public to act calmly and tune into media for updated information.<ref name="bl" /><ref name="nk">{{cite web|url=http://e.nikkei.com/e/fr/tnks/Nni20110311D11JF296.htm|title=Govt Takes Emergency Steps, Kan Asks People To Stay Calm|date=11 March 2011|author=Nikkei Inc.|publisher=Nikkei.com}}</ref> He reported that numerous nuclear power plants were automatically shut down to prevent damage and releases of radioactivity.<ref name="bl">{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-03-11/kan-mobilizes-forces-central-bank-pledges-liquidity-after-japanese-quake.html|title=Kan Mobilizes Forces, BOJ Pledges Liquidity After Quake|date=11 March 2011|author=Christopher Anstey|work=Bloomberg}}</ref> He set up emergency headquarters in his office to coordinate the government's response.<ref name="nk" />
Evacuation shelters faced a shortage of potable water, food, blankets and bathroom facilities, as the government arranged these necessities to be delivered to where they were needed from areas of Japan and abroad.<ref>{{Cite news|title=After Japan's quake and tsunami, freezing weather threatens relief efforts|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/mar/16/japan-quake-tsunami-freezing-temperatures-relief|accessdate=17 March 2011|newspaper=[[The Guardian]]|date=16 March 2011|location=London|first=Jonathan|last=Watts| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110317145710/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/mar/16/japan-quake-tsunami-freezing-temperatures-relief| archivedate= 17 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Dropping temperatures, due to the disruption in electrical and gas lines, caused further problems at shelters.<ref name="nhk-english-stream">{{cite web|url=http://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/r0/high.asx |title=World English |accessdate=12 March 2011 |date=12 March 2011 |publisher=NHK |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110313065747/http://www3.nhk.or.jp/nhkworld/r0/high.asx |archivedate=13 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> {{As of|2011|03|17}}, 336,521 people in Japan had been displaced from their homes and were residing elsewhere, including in 2,367 shelters.<ref>NHK, 17 Mar, 04:01 am. Evacuees by prefecture: Miyagi- 205,418, Fukushima- 64,040, Iwate- 44,433, Yamagata- 2,217, Aomori- 371, Akita- 40, Ibaragi- 12,347, Chiba- 1,010, Tochigi- 1,696, Gunma- 63, Saitama- 107, Niigata- 3,200, Nagano- 1,579.</ref>
A Japanese [[urban search and rescue]] team sent to New Zealand following the February [[2011 Christchurch earthquake]] was recalled.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://bigpondnews.com/articles/World/2011/03/12/Japanese_rescue_team_in_NZ_heads_home_588071.html|title=Japanese rescue team in NZ heads home|publisher=BigPond News|date=12 March 2011}}</ref> On 27 March 2011, Japan's [[National Police Agency (Japan)|National Police Agency]] reported that 14 of its officers had died in the line of duty in the disaster and a further 16 were missing.<ref>Schreiber, Mark, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fd20110327bj.html Local media react to the events of March 11]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 27 March 2011, p. 9.</ref>
The government in Japan committed to cleaning up the damage from the disaster, an effort forecast to cost a total of ¥1 trillion (US$8 billion).<ref>[[Agence France-Presse]]/[[Jiji Press]], "Radiation, legalities complicate cleanup efforts", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 9 April 2011, p. 2.</ref>
The government set up an advisory panel of intellectual figures on 14 April 2011, named the {{nihongo|Reconstruction Design Council in Response to the Great East Japan Earthquake |[[:ja:東日本大震災復興構想会議]]}} and chaired by Makoto Iokibe, President of the [[National Defense Academy of Japan]]. The Council submitted the first set of recommendations to the government for the third supplementary budget for full-fledged reconstruction measures on 25 June.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.asahi.com/english/TKY201106270158.html |title = Tax hikes for reconstruction face stiff opposition |publisher = The Asahi Shimbun |date = 28 June 2011}}</ref> The government struggled to produce a plan for the clean up of the 2.8 million tons of debris in Fukushima Prefecture, as much of it is radioactive.<ref>Hongo, Jun, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110701f1.html Radioactive debris dilemma unresolved, growing worse]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 1 July 2011, p. 3.</ref>
Many seaside communities in Japan have reexamined their tsunami defenses and reaction plans in response to the disaster.<ref>Corkill, Edan, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/fl20120226x1.html Danger zones]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 26 February 2012, p. 7.</ref>
The public and companies were encouraged to conserve electricity in the 2011 summer months ([[Setsuden]]).<ref>Rubin, Jeffrey [http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jeffrey-rubin/setsuden-japan-nuclear-free_b_916123.html "Setsuden Poised to Replace Nuclear Power in Japan "]"[[The Huffington Post]]", 4 August 2011. Retrieved 6 February 2011</ref>
In March 2012 the Tokyo Metropolitan Government passed the [[Metropolitan Tokyo Ordinance on Measures for Stranded Individuals]] requiring employers to stockpile food, water and emergency supplies at their places of business. It came into effect on 1 April 2013.<ref>Tokyo Metropolitan Government Disaster prevention website [Metropolitan Tokyo Ordinance on Measures for Stranded Persons {{cite web|url=http://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.jp/foreign/english/kitaku_portal/2000188.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-10-08 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140614051040/http://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.jp/foreign/english/kitaku_portal/2000188.html |archivedate=14 June 2014 |df=dmy }}] Retrieved 8 October 2014</ref>
Japanese media reported in 2012 that up to 25% of special funds allocated by the government for disaster recovery and relief were being used outside the disaster area on projects unrelated to the earthquake and tsunami. The projects included ¥500 million (US$4 million) for road construction in Okinawa, ¥330 million (US$3 million) for repairs to [[National Olympic Stadium (Tokyo)|National Stadium]], ¥10.7 million (US$95 thousand) in subsidies for nuclear research, ¥30 million (US$269 thousand) for power shovels for prisons in Hokkaido and Saitama, and ¥2.3 billion (US$20 million) to combat the [[Sea Shepherd Conservation Society]]. In the meantime, in October 2012 the damaged towns in Tōhoku reported that they were still struggling to recover from the disaster.<ref>Aoki, Mizuho and Reiji Yoshida, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20121026f1.html Misuse of disaster 'reconstruction' money runs rampant]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 26 October 2012, p. 3</ref>
===Citizens=== [[File:Fundraiser for victims of the Tohoku Earthquake 1.JPG|thumb|Fundraising drive for disaster victims]]
There was a notable lack of disorder immediately following the earthquake. This was attributed to Japanese forbearance, an attitude sometimes referred to as [[Gaman (term)|gaman]],<ref>{{cite web|title=Crushed, but true to law of 'gaman'|url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/crushed-but-true-to-law-of-gaman/story-fn84naht-1226022079002|work=The Australian |accessdate=18 March 2011|date=16 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110324003246/http://www.theaustralian.com.au/crushed-but-true-to-law-of-gaman/story-fn84naht-1226022079002| archivedate= 24 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> and to laws that encourage honesty and a strong police presence. One source reported that the three main clans of [[Yakuza]] gangs were enforcing order in their territories.<ref name=beam20110316>{{Cite news|author=Beam, Christopher|title=Stop, Thief! Thank You.|url=http://www.slate.com/id/2288514 |publisher=Slate |date=16 March 2011|accessdate=19 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110330143125/http://www.slate.com//id//2288514| archivedate= 30 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> A Mark MacKinnon wrote in ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'' wrote, "As one catastrophe piled on top of another, a very Japanese deference to authority emerged, as well as a national desire to see civility prevail, no matter the circumstances."<ref>{{Cite news |author=MacKinnon, Mark |title=National stoicism helps Japan manage disaster recovery |url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/asia-pacific/national-stoicism-helps-japan-manage-disaster-recovery/article1940630/|date=15 March 2011|work=Globe and Mail |accessdate=16 March 2011|location=Toronto| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110317002551/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/asia-pacific/national-stoicism-helps-japan-manage-disaster-recovery/article1940630/| archivedate= 17 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
Some people devastated by the quake began, however, to question the government's effort in providing food, clothing, electricity, heat, and phone service.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-japan-quake-slow-aid-20110319,0,7633226,full.story |title=Japan earthquake: Residents of Japan's quake region wonder where the government is |last=Magnier |first=Mark |first2=Barbara |last2=Demick |date=18 March 2011 |work=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=18 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xHqCvdCM?url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-japan-quake-slow-aid-20110319,0,7633226,full.story |archivedate=18 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> [[Chief Cabinet Secretary]] [[Yukio Edano]] later said, "In hindsight, we could have moved a little quicker in assessing the situation and coordinating all that information and provided it faster."<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gI6DCsmEuRwI3Y1Z1Otl4akQ-2GA?docId=c3827c1a078c46d9ab4451ed41d8641e |title=A week after quake, Japan's leader vows to rebuild |date=19 March 2011 |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=19 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xHy55HOD?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5gI6DCsmEuRwI3Y1Z1Otl4akQ-2GA?docId=c3827c1a078c46d9ab4451ed41d8641e |archivedate=19 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref>
[[File:US Navy 110315-N-5503T-474 Naval Aircrewman 2nd Class Chris Carringer, assigned to the Black Knights of Helicopter Anti-Submarine Squadron (HS) 4,.jpg|thumb|left|Civilians form a human chain to speed unloading of a U.S. military relief supply flight]]
Some ten days after the quake, reports began to emerge of incidents of [[looting]] and theft in quake and tsunami-hit areas. By 20 March 2011, 250 thefts, with ¥4.9 million (US$43 thousand) in merchandise stolen from stores and ¥5.8 million (US$52 thousand) in cash, were reported to the Miyagi Prefectural Police. Witnesses reported thieves stealing cash and bank books from smashed houses, looting goods from stores, and siphoning gas from abandoned or damaged vehicles.<ref>[[Agence France-Presse]] and [[Jiji Press]], "Desperation tests crime taboo", ''Japan Times'', 21 March 2011, p. 2.</ref><ref>[[Jiji Press]], "Thieves, looters targeting Miyagi's quake-hit stores", ''Japan Times'', 21 March 2011, p. 2.</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/japan-earthquake-and-tsunami-in/8395153/Japan-earthquake-Looting-reported-by-desperate-survivors.html |title=Japan earthquake: Looting reported by desperate survivors |last=Allen |first=Nick |date=21 March 2011 |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xMHawuzX?url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/asia/japan/japan-earthquake-and-tsunami-in/8395153/Japan-earthquake-Looting-reported-by-desperate-survivors.html |archivedate=21 March 2011 |location=London |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> Around ¥40 million (US$358 thousand) was reportedly stolen from a bank in Kesennuma, Miyagi.<ref>Gilhooly, Rob, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20110327x1.html Survivors strive to start picking up the pieces]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 27 March 2011, p. 7.</ref>
Between 11 March and the end of June 2011, a total of ¥684.4 million (US$6 million) was stolen from ATMs and convenience stores in Fukushima, Miyagi, and Iwate prefectures. Of the money stolen, ¥477 million (US$4 million) from 34 ATM thefts took place in Fukushima Prefecture, 80% of that in the 20-km evacuation zone around the Daiichi nuclear plant. The number of thefts from homes and stores during the same period in those three prefectures stood at 1,233, about 1.5 times the number from the same period in 2010. Of them, 194 were in the nuclear evacuation zone, 19 times the number from 2010. The rumors which had spread immediately after the quake of rampant rapes by armed gangs proved to be false, as reports of sexual assaults actually fell 35.7 percent to 81 cases. Only one sexual assault was reported occurring in one of the evacuee centers. Throughout Japan, there were 51 reported cases of scams or frauds related to the disaster, with losses amounting to around ¥12.6 million (US$112 thousand).<ref>[[Jiji Press]]/[[Kyodo News]], "¥684 million (US$6 million) stolen from ATMs in hardest-hit prefectures", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 16 July 2011, p. 1.</ref>
Even though there are no regulations imposed by the Japan government for conservation, many people practised self-restraint by conserving resources and cancelling celebrations, this reaction was attributed by experts as a way of coping with the traumatising scale of losses and the spreading fear of radioactive fallout.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.deccanherald.com/content/151147/in-wake-tragedy-japanese-usher.html |title=Japanese usher in era of self-restraint |newspaper=Deccan Herald |date=29 March 2011 |publisher=The New York Times |page=A6 |accessdate=20 May 2013}}</ref>
As of December 2011, there were 2,439 complaints lodged with the [[National Consumer Affairs Center of Japan]] concerning earthquake-related scams from throughout Japan. A total of ¥970 million had been paid or lost by those targeted by the alleged scams. The reported scams included exorbitant house and roof repairs, faulty radiation gauges, and water filters touted to remove radioactivity.<ref>[[Kyodo News]], "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn20111226a5.html Scams targeting disaster victims]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 26 December 2011, p. 2.</ref>
The government raised the [[International Nuclear Event Scale|level 7]] severity of the nuclear accident after the [[Japanese unified regional elections, 2011]].
Non-government organizations, including [[Peace Boat]], have assisted in cleaning up the disaster area since the quake.<ref>Lee, Andrew, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20110508x1.html A volunteer's journal of hope for Tohoku]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 8 May 2011, p. 7.</ref>
===Non-citizen residents of Japan=== Approximately 531,000 non-Japanese residing in Japan departed the country after the quake and tsunami, including approximately 25% of foreigners living in Tokyo. Foreigners living in Japan and the English-language media in Japan coined the term "[[flyjin]]" (or fly-jin), a play on the Japanese word [[gaijin]], as a label for the non-Japanese who fled in the wake of the disaster.<ref>''[[Metropolis (free magazine)|Metropolis]]'', "The Small Print: See Ya!", No. 893, 6–19 May 2011, p. 4.</ref><ref>Gondor, Derek, "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20110405zg.html 'Fly-jin' face fallout from decision to go]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 5 April 2011.</ref><ref>[[Debito Arudou|Arudou, Debito]], "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/fl20110503ad.html Better to be branded a 'flyjin' than a man of the 'sheeple']", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 3 May 2011.</ref><ref>Gurumurthy, R., "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/rc20110410a1.html Bad habit of judging foreigners]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 10 April 2011; ''[[Japan Times]]'', "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/ed20120506a2.html 'Flyjin' rather few]", 6 May 2012, p. 6</ref>
9,720 dependents of United States military and government civilian employees in Japan fled the country, mainly to the United States.<ref>Tritten, Travis J., "[http://www.stripes.com/news/pacific/earthquake-disaster-in-japan/evacuation-from-japan-a-vacation-not-so-much-1.145198 Evacuation from Japan a vacation? Not so much]," ''[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]'', 31 May 2011.</ref> The United States spent $11.7 million on chartered aircraft to fly the dependents out of the country.<ref>Tritten, Travis J., "[http://www.stripes.com/news/pacific/earthquake-disaster-in-japan/u-s-spent-11-7m-to-fly-dependents-out-of-japan-after-earthquake-1.147677 U.S. spent $11.7M to fly dependents out of Japan after earthquake]", ''[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]'', 28 June 2011.</ref>
The number of foreign residents in Japan dropped by 55,000 in 2011, with Iwate losing 15.5%, Fukushima 15.1%, and Miyagi 13.2% of their populations of non-Japanese. The total reduction in foreigners nationwide was 2.6% of the pre-quake total.<ref name="Metropolis 2012, p. 4"/>
===Media===
The former Japanese participant of [[Korean Broadcasting System]]'s ''[[Global Talk Show]]'' Junko Sagawa criticized the Japanese government for "intentionally ignoring the Japanese citizens during the tsunami and the nuclear crisis" through her personal homepage on 17 March 2011.<ref>{{cite news | script-title=ko:'미수다' 준코, 日 정부 공개 비난 "위험없다는 말은 더 이상 듣고 싶지 않아" | date = 19 March 2011 | url = http://bntnews.hankyung.com/apps/news?popup=0&nid=04&c1=04&c2=04&c3=00&nkey=201103191224503&mode=sub_view | work = bntnews (Hankyung.com) | accessdate =31 August 2011 | language = Korean}}</ref>
The earthquake postponed the [[analog shutdown]] in the Iwate, Miyagi, and Fukushima prefectures. Television stations in these three prefectures shut off their analog signals on 31 March 2012 at noon. Television stations in the Yamagata, Aomori, and Akita prefectures shut down their analog signals on 24 July 2011, along with the rest of Japan.
==International response== {{main|Humanitarian response to the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami}}
[[File:US Navy 110321-N-9436A-099 Cryptologic Technician (Collection) 2nd Class Gregory Allison, left center, from Glen Burnie, Md.jpg|thumb|US and French military troops aid civilians in the cleanup]]
===Request for assistance=== Japan specifically requested teams from Australia, New Zealand, [[South Korea]], and the United States;<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/11/us-japan-quake-aid-refile-idUSTRE72A71320110311|title=Japan requests foreign rescue teams, UN says|last=Nebehay|first=Stephanie|date=11 March 2011|agency=Reuters |accessdate=11 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002542/https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/11/us-japan-quake-aid-refile-idUSTRE72A71320110311| archivedate= 16 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> it also requested, via its space agency [[JAXA]], the activation of the [[International Charter on Space and Major Disasters]], allowing diverse satellite imagery of affected regions to be readily shared with rescue and aid organizations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.disasterscharter.org/web/charter/activation_details?p_r_p_1415474252_assetId=ACT-359 |title=Disaster Charter – Earthquake in Japan |publisher=Disasterscharter.org |date=28 May 2010 |accessdate=12 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110316002512/http://www.disasterscharter.org/web/charter/activation_details?p_r_p_1415474252_assetId=ACT-359 |archivedate=16 March 2011 |deadurl=yes }}</ref>
===World involvement=== Japan received messages of condolence and offers of assistance from a range of international leaders. According to Japan's foreign ministry On 19 March 2011, 128 countries and 33 international organizations had offered assistance to Japan.<ref name="Reuters figures">{{cite news |last=Nomiyama |first=Chiz |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/21/us-japan-quake-numbers-idUSTRE72K0YJ20110321 |title=Factbox: Japan disaster in figures |date=21 March 2011 |work=Reuters |accessdate=21 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xLOSexvL?url=http://www.reuters.com/assets/print?aid=USTRE72K0YJ20110321 |archivedate=21 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The EU has also been more than ready to offer its support to them: "An earthquake powerful enough to make the world wobble on its axis, a massive tsunami, an emergency in nuclear power stations. Any one of these would be a tragedy. Thousands of people have died and this has turned this tragedy into a catastrophe," said Herman van Rompuy, President of the European Council.<ref>{{cite web|title=Japan live blog: Nuclear crisis|url=http://www.channel4.com/news/japan-live-blog-nuclear-crisis|publisher=Channel 4|accessdate=16 March 2011|author=Channel 4 News|date=16 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110317002551/http://www.channel4.com/news/japan-live-blog-nuclear-crisis| archivedate= 17 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> Twenty [[Member state of the European Union|Member States]] have offered assistance through the European Civil Protection Mechanism.<ref>{{cite web|title=The European Union's response to the earthquake and the nuclear plant situation in Japan |url=http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO/11/166 |publisher=Europa |accessdate=16 March 2011 |date=14 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317002552/http://europa.eu/rapid/pressReleasesAction.do?reference=MEMO%2F11%2F166 |archivedate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> Australian Prime Minister [[Julia Gillard]] was the first foreign leader to visit the earthquake site
The Fukushima incident brought the issue of nuclear power to the fore internationally, causing an anti-nuclear demonstration of 50,000 people in [[Stuttgart]] and the cancellation of a pro-nuclear press conference in the United Kingdom.
[[File:PowerTruckJapan2011.JPG|thumb|left|Electric utility trucks are transported to the tsunami zone by sea]]

web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/s/nm/20110315/wl_nm/us_japan_quake_china|title=China evacuates citizens from Japan quake areas|publisher=Yahoo!}}</ref> France had also officially begun evacuation of its nationals from the worst-hit areas, dispatching airliners to assist in the evacuation on 16 March 2011.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-pacific-12763273|title=Japan |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-1366920/Japan-earthquake-tsunami-Governments-tell-citizens-leave-toxic-radiation-zone.html |title=Japan earthquake and tsunami: UN predicts nuclear plume
