Search.japantimes.co.jp. Retrieved on 26 March 2011.</ref>
[[File:JSDFmatsushimaEast.jpg|thumb|Japanese and US military personnel construct temporary buildings for disaster victims]]
In many countries, both government and private aid campaigns have been organized to offer money and support to the victims and general populace of Japan. Social buying sites have launched on-line campaigns in which several million dollars were raised for relief organizations working in Japan.<ref>{{Cite news|publisher=Pinggers Blog|url = http://blog.pinggers.com/2011/03/after-japan%E2%80%99s-earthquake-daily-deals-became-a-useful-tool-for-daily-giving/|title = After Japan's Earthquake, Daily Deals became a Useful Tool for Daily Giving}}</ref> As of 3 April 2011, the [[Japanese Red Cross]] had received over $1 billion in donations in response to the disaster, and dispatched more than 200 emergency relief teams to the disaster zone. However it received criticism from some quarters for not yet having dispensed any cash aid to survivors.<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fgw-japan-relief-20110404,0,7537892.story Red Cross aid hasn't reached Japan quake victims], ''LA Times'', 3 April 2011.</ref> The [[American Red Cross]] said that it had received $120 million in donations from the US public.<ref>''[[NHK]]'', "Red Cross donates millions", 30 March 2011.</ref> The Singapore Red Cross and Japan Association said that, as of 31 March 2011, residents of Singapore had donated [[Singapore dollar|S$]] 3.15 million for disaster relief.<ref>''[[Channel News Asia]]'', "Contributions for Japan quake victims continue to pour in", 4 April 2011.</ref>
As of May 2011, contributors in South Korea had donated ₩56 billion won (US$50 million) to various organizations for the disaster relief effort.<ref>''[[Yonhap]]'', "S. Korean relief groups collect W56 bln for Japan", 18 April 2011.</ref> By May 2011 the people of Taiwan had donated or pledged 5.9 billion Taiwan dollars (US$216 million).<ref>Shu-ling, Ko, ([[Kyodo News]]), "[http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20110521f1.html Intricate bonds behind Taiwan aid]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 21 May 2011, p. 3.</ref>
[[Operation Tomodachi]], which means ''Friend'' in Japanese, was the United States military operation to provide assistance and humanitarian aid to Japan. Twenty-thousand US military personnel, including 19 naval vessels and 120 aircraft, were mobilized to provide assistance or move supplies to the disaster area. The US aid efforts were conducted under the direction of Japanese government or military authorities.<ref>''[[Sankei Shimbun]]'', "Life in the balance-- Operation Tomodachi", 27 March 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=134878879 |title=Disaster Aid Puts New Face On US Military In Japan |date=26 March 2011 |work=[[NPR]] |agency=Associated Press |accessdate=27 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5xVV0RgsD?url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=134878879 |archivedate=27 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> The ''[[Yomiuri Shimbun]]'' reported that the "coordinated relief activities at the disaster sites are expected to deepen the Japan-U.S. alliance."<ref>{{Cite news|title=Japan-U.S. relief efforts expanding |url=http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110319003100.htm |archive-url=https://wayback.archive-it.org/all/20110320213514/http://www.yomiuri.co.jp/dy/national/T110319003100.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=20 March 2011 |newspaper=The Daily Yomiuri |author=Yomiuri Shimbun |location=Japan |date=20 March 2011 |accessdate=19 March 2011 |df= }}</ref>
A number of religious groups donated funds, equipment, supplies, or volunteer time. The [[Hinokishin]] Brigade of [[Tenrikyo]] donated ¥920 million, [[Sōka Gakkai]] ¥500 million, [[Risshō Kōsei Kai]] ¥500 million, [[Seicho-no-Ie]] ¥250 million, [[Unification Church]] ¥160 million, [[Science of Happiness]] ¥61 million, and various other Buddhist charities ¥340 million.<ref>Schreiber, Mark, "[http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/fd20120506pb.html Weeklies take a look at faiths, (misplaced) hopes and charities]", ''[[Japan Times]]'', 6 May 2012, p. 9.</ref>
===Information and support=== Among several resources offered to help find earthquake survivors and obtain information about people in Japan are: Disaster Message Board Web171 operated by [[Nippon Telegraph and Telephone]],<ref>{{Cite news|publisher=Tokyo|url = http://www.bousai.metro.tokyo.jp/english/e-message/|title = Disaster message telephone and message board (broadband and narrowband)}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url = https://www.web171.jp/top.php|title = Web171|access-date = 1 April 2011|archive-url = https://www.webcitation.org/5xC0row3w?url=https://www.web171.jp/top.php|archive-date = 15 March 2011|dead-url = yes|df = dmy-all}}</ref> the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]],<ref>{{Cite news|title = Family links|publisher=International Committee of the Red Cross|url = http://www.familylinks.icrc.org/eng/familylinks-japan}}</ref> [[American Red Cross]],<ref>[http://www2.nbc4i.com/news/2011/mar/14/red-cross-says-you-can-donate-directly-japan-victi-ar-423274/ Red Cross Accepts Donation For Japan Victims] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110331005144/http://www2.nbc4i.com/news/2011/mar/14/red-cross-says-you-can-donate-directly-japan-victi-ar-423274/ |date=31 March 2011 }}, NBC4i.com, 26 March 2011</ref> [[Google Person Finder]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://japan.person-finder.appspot.com/ |title=Google Person Finder |language=ja |publisher=Japan.person-finder.appspot.com |accessdate=26 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110326010631/http://japan.person-finder.appspot.com/ |archivedate=26 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref> websites of the Australian Embassy,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.australia.or.jp/en/ |title=Australian Embassy |publisher=Australia.or.jp |accessdate=18 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110317002612/http://www.australia.or.jp/en/| archivedate= 17 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> [[US Department of State]],<ref>{{cite web|url=https://travel.state.gov/travel/cis_pa_tw/pa/pa_5378.html |title=US Department of State |publisher=Travel.state.gov |date=14 March 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110317002421/http://travel.state.gov/travel/cis_pa_tw/pa/pa_5378.html| archivedate= 17 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> UK [[Foreign and Commonwealth Office]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/news/latest-news/?view=News&id=564374182 |title=UK Foreign and Commonwealth Office |publisher=Fco.gov.uk |date=11 March 2011 |accessdate=18 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317002614/http://www.fco.gov.uk/en/news/latest-news/?view=News&id=564374182 |archivedate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref> and the Honshū Quake wiki operated by the [[Crisis camp|CrisisCommons]] volunteer community.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Japanese-PM-Appeals-for-Unity-to-Face-Earthquake--117895114.html|title=Japanese Engineers Struggle With Several Damaged Nuclear Reactors|publisher=Voice of America|accessdate=14 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110314025238/http://www.voanews.com/english/news/Japanese-PM-Appeals-for-Unity-to-Face-Earthquake--117895114.html| archivedate= 14 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> On 27 March 2013, [[Google]] released [[street view]] imagery for the city of [[Namie]] within the exclusion zone, following requests from former residents.
==Sports== The [[2011 World Figure Skating Championships]] were scheduled to take place from 21–27 March at the [[Yoyogi National Gymnasium]] in Tokyo but the [[International Skating Union]] decided on 14 March to postpone the event, after the German team announced that it would follow recommendations not to travel to Japan.<ref name="asspressmarch13">{{Cite news|url = https://www.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/2011-03-13-skating-worlds-japan_N.htm|title = Germany pulls out of skating worlds in Japan|date = 13 March 2011|agency=Associated Press |work=USA Today|accessdate =13 March 2011}}</ref> After Japanese officials announced it would not be possible to host the event in the country, it was moved to late April in Moscow, Russia.<ref name=wfsppap>{{cite news | url = https://www.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/2011-03-24-skating-worlds-moscow_N.htm | title = With Tokyo out, Moscow to host figure skating worlds |date = 24 March 2011 | agency = Associated Press |work=USA Today | accessdate =31 March 2011}}</ref> The 2011 [[ISU World Team Trophy in Figure Skating]], scheduled for [[Yokohama]] on 14–17 April, was postponed until the following year.
The Japanese Olympic Committee denied reports that it had abandoned plans to bid for the [[2020 Olympics]] and said it was still under consideration.<ref name=2020olybid>{{cite news | url = https://www.usatoday.com/sports/olympics/2011-03-23-1231252815_x.htm | title = Japan still considering 2020 Olympic bid | first = Stephen | last =Wilson |date = 23 March 2011 | agency = Associated Press |work=USA Today | accessdate =31 March 2011}}</ref> In April 2011, Japanese Olympic officials stated they were undecided whether to run but said hosting international sports events was important to helping the country rebuild.<ref name=rebuild>{{cite news | url = http://sports.espn.com/espn/wire?section=oly&id=6300596 | title = Japan looking to sports to help rebuild country | date = 6 April 2011 | agency = Associated Press | publisher = [[ESPN]] | accessdate = 6 April 2011 }}{{Dead link|date=October 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> In July 2011, Tokyo put forth its [[Tokyo bid for the 2020 Summer Olympics|bid]] to host the 2020 Summer Olympic Games.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/15/olympics-tokyo-bid-idUSL3E7IF1XH20110715 | work=Reuters | first=Alastair | last=Himmer | title=Olympics-Tokyo tiptoes into 2020 bid race | date=15 July 2011}}</ref> Following the deadline for bidding, the [[IOC]] confirmed that Tokyo was one of the six cities that had entered a bid.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.olympic.org/content/press-release/six-applicant-cities-for-the-2020-olympic-games/|title=Press releases|date=2016-07-18|access-date=2016-07-19}}</ref> The bid has received the full support of the government.<ref>[http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2020_bid_news/1216135994.html National Government Backs Tokyo 2020] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120103150326/http://www.gamesbids.com/eng/olympic_bids/2020_bid_news/1216135994.html |date=3 January 2012 }}</ref> On 23 May 2012, the [[IOC]] selected Tokyo as one of the three candidate cities for the 2020 Olympics. On 7 September 2013, Tokyo was voted to host the [[2020 Summer Olympics]] with 60 votes to 36 in the final round against Istanbul.
[[File:F1 2011 AUS - 5CROP.jpg|thumb|left|Message of support for Japan, seen on [[Sauber C30]] during [[2011 Australian Grand Prix]]]]
The 2011 [[Japanese motorcycle Grand Prix]], originally scheduled for 24 April, was moved to 2 October.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/89946|title=Japanese MotoGP moves to October|first=Matt|last=Beer|work=[[Autosport]]|publisher=[[Haymarket Group|Haymarket Publications]]|date=15 March 2011|accessdate=15 March 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110317002532/http://www.autosport.com/news/report.php/id/89946| archivedate= 17 March 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.motogp.com/en/news/2011/Japan+GP+postponed |title=FIM Announcement: Grand Prix of Japan postponed |work=motogp.com |publisher=[[Dorna Sports]] |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=15 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110317002541/http://www.motogp.com/en/news/2011/Japan%2BGP%2Bpostponed |archivedate=17 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
The 18 September [[IndyCar]] race at Motegi, Japan, the Indy Japan Final, was moved from the Superspeedway to the Road Course because of damage to the Superspeedway (2.5 kilometres oval) to the 4.7 km road course, and reduced from 482 miles to 300 km.
The 2011 Asia League Ice Hockey finals between the Tōhoku Free Blades and Anyang Halla were to begin on 11 March but the five games were canceled.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.alhockey.com/news/2011/03/cancellation-of-playoff-finals-and-the-final-ranking-of-2010-2011-season.html |date=22 March 2011 |title=Cancellation of Playoff Finals and the Final Ranking of 2010-2011 Season |accessdate=20 May 2013}}</ref> {{As of|2011|03|14}}, no rescheduled dates were announced.
The [[Japanese national football team]] canceled their friendly match with [[Montenegro national football team|Montenegro]] scheduled for 25 March in [[Shizuoka, Shizuoka|Shizuoka]]. They were also scheduled to play [[New Zealand national football team|New Zealand]] in Tokyo on 29 March, although the [[Japan Football Association]] tried to relocate the match to [[Osaka]], much further away from the affected area. "We hope to play New Zealand, which like Japan has also suffered damage from [[February 2011 Christchurch earthquake|a big earthquake]]," Japan FA president Junji Ogura said in a statement.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/news/newsid=1399596.html |title=Japan cancel friendly, hope for NZ game |publisher=FIFA.com |accessdate=19 March 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110324003313/http://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/news/newsid%3D1399596.html |archivedate=24 March 2011 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref> In the end, the "All Whites" canceled their plans to play the Japanese due to safety concerns.<ref>[https://www.fifa.com/worldfootball/news/newsid=1407124.html Blue Samurai ready to lift quake-hit Japan]. FIFA.com (2011-03-27). Retrieved on 1 April 2011.</ref>
Owing to power restrictions, the 2011 Nippon Professional Baseball season featured a regular season restriction; no inning may start three hours and thirty minutes after the first pitch has been thrown in the game. Furthermore, if a power outage occurs during the game, the game ends.
The [[International Tennis Federation|ITF]] tennis tournament, Japan Future 1, was to take place on [[Nishitama District, Tokyo]] from 14–20 March and was cancelled after the qualifying round was completed. The series of four [[Futures tournament|ITF Men’s Circuit Futures]] tournaments in and around Tokyo, commencing the week of 14 March 2011 has been cancelled.
Due to uncertainty over the nuclear situation, the [[International Federation of Gymnastics]] was considering moving the [[2011 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships]], however they went ahead as planned.<ref name=gymnworlds>{{cite news | url = https://www.google.com/hostednews/canadianpress/article/ALeqM5g-315c9Wn8mu3DdjjH98pNul7nWw?docId=6419414 | title = Gymnastics body to weigh moving worlds as concern grows over 'nuclear catastrophe' |date = 31 March 2011 | agency = Associated Press | accessdate =31 March 2011}}</ref>
==Debris overseas== On 21 September 2012, the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] announced that a large blue plastic storage bin from [[Fukushima, Fukushima|Fukushima]] was the first confirmed piece of marine debris that had arrived in waters off Hawaii. This was the 12th confirmed piece of Japanese tsunami debris to arrive in United States or Canadian waters.<ref>{{cite web|title=BIN IN HAWAII CONFIRMED TO BE JAPAN TSUNAMI DEBRIS|url=http://bigstory.ap.org/article/bin-hawaii-confirmed-be-japan-tsunami-debris|publisher=AP|accessdate=21 September 2012}}</ref>
On 30 November 2012, Prime Minister Noda announced the Government of Japan had decided to extend an ex gratia gift to the government of the United States in the wake of the Great East Japan earthquake to demonstrate goodwill with respect to tsunami debris.<ref name="Nov 30 debris">{{cite news|title=The gift of five million dollars to the Government of the United States of America with respect to tsunami debris deriving from the Great East Japan Earthquake|accessdate=30 November 2012|newspaper=Embassy of Japan|date=30 November 2012|url=http://www.us.emb-japan.go.jp/english/html/pressreleases/2012/gift%20for%20tsunami%20debris.html}}</ref>
During March 2013, a boat lost during the tsunami washed up on the shores of Washington, U.S. carrying five trapped live fish. The surviving [[Tsunami fish]] was put on display at the [[Seaside Aquarium]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.oregonlive.com/pacific-northwest-news/index.ssf/2013/04/tiny_fish_that_survived_tsunam.html | title=Tiny fish that survived tsunami, ocean crossing from Japan makes debut in Seaside | publisher=The Oregonian | date=5 April 2013 | accessdate=28 December 2013 | author=Tobias, Lori}}</ref> Between September 2015 and March 2016, 64 items that have washed up on the coastline of North America have been identified as being debris from the tsunami.<ref>{{cite web | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-asia-35638091 | title=Japan's tsunami debris: Five remarkable stories| publisher=BBC News| date=9 March 2015 | accessdate=9 March 2015}}</ref>
==Asteroid naming== Multiple asteroid have been named in relations to the earthquake. In the Asteroids, Comets, Meteors 2012 conference which was held at Toki Messe in [[Niigata, Niigata|Niigata]], [[International Astronomical Union]] approved naming 12 asteroids after area affected by the earthquake, in hopes for their recovery. The 12 asteroids, including [[14701 Aizu]], [[19534 Miyagi]], [[19691 Iwate]], [[19701 Aomori]], [[19713 Ibaraki]], [[19731 Tochigi]], [[20613 Chibaken]], [[21966 Hamadori]], [[22719 Nakadori]], [[22745 Rikuzentakata]], [[22885 Sakaemura]], and [[22914 Tsunanmachi]] were all discovered by [[Lowell Observatory]] in the [[Lowell Observatory Near-Earth-Object Search]] project, which have the right to propose the naming of these asteroids and is officially the proposer of these names, although the naming proposal itself was initially drafts by local organizing committee for the conference.<ref name="IAUasteroid2012">[https://www.nao.ac.jp/en/news/topics/2012/20120509-asteroid.html Astronomers Pray to the Stars for Recovery: Asteroids Named after Disaster-Stricken Prefectures and Other Areas]</ref>
The asteroid [[23649 Tohoku]] is also named after the area affected by the earthquake to commemorate all the people died during the disaster,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://headlines.yahoo.co.jp/hl?a=20120306-00000054-mailo-l03|archiveurl=http://teishoin.net/blog/004510.html|archivedate=2012-03-06|date=2012-03-06|accessdate=2017-11-02|title=小惑星：アマチュア天文家・佐藤さん、「Ｔｏｈｏｋｕ」と命名 ３．１１南の空に輝く |publisher=Mainichi Shimbun|language=ja}}</ref> asteroid [[29157 Higashinihon]] is named as such in hope for recovery from the earthquake,<ref>[http://comet-seki.net/Syouwakusei.html 関勉発見の小惑星一覧 コメットハンター関勉のホームページ]</ref> and asteroid [[31152 Daishinsai]] is also named after the earthquake to commemorate the event and wish for people died from its.<ref>[http://www.47news.jp/m/news/201205/kj_2012050800161.php 小惑星に「Ｄａｉｓｈｉｎｓａｉ」 復興を願い命名] Kyodo News 2012-05-08</ref>

The '''Aspurgiani''' ([[Greek language|Greek]]: {{lang|grc|Ἀσπουργιανοί}} or {{lang|grc|Ἀσπουγγιτανοί}}) were an ancient people, a tribe of the [[Maeotae]] dwelling along east side of the [[Strait of Kerch]] along the [[Palus Maeotis]] in antiquity. They seem to be identical with the "[[Asturicani]]" of [[Ptolemy]] (v. 9. § 7).
The Aspurgiani inhabited the region called [[Sindica]], between [[Phanagoria]] and [[Gorgippia]], among the Maeotae, [[Sindi (people)|Sindi]], [[Dandarii]], [[Toreatae]], [[Agri (Maeotae)|Agri]], [[Arrechi]], [[Tarpetes]], [[Obidiaceni]], [[Sittaceni]] and [[Dosci]], among others. (Strab. xi. 2. 11). They were among the Maeotic tribes whom King [[Polemon I of Pontus]] and [[Bosporan kingdom|the Bosporus]], in the reign of [[Roman Emperor]] [[Augustus]], attempted to subdue; however, they took him prisoner and put him to death. (Strab. xi. p. 495, xii. p. 556; [[Stephanus of Byzantium|Steph. B.]] ''s. v.''; see Ritter's speculations on the name, in connection with the origin of the name of Asia, Vorhalle, pp. 296, foil.).
Scholars often attribute artifacts found in the Bosporus and Gorgippia, which featured the [[Solar deity|Sun god]] or its symbols, to the Aspurgiani tribes, indicating their Iranian descent.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Intangible Spirits and Graven Images: The Iconography of Deities in the Pre-Islamic Iranian World|last=Shaked|first=Shaul|last2=Bhayro|first2=Siam|publisher=BRILL|year=2014|isbn=9789004281486|location=Leiden|pages=105}}</ref> These tribes were first mentioned in Strabo's works as the group who killed Polemo when he launched a treacherous attack.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Scythians and Greeks: A Survey of Ancient History and Archaeology on the North Coast of the Euxine from the Danube to the Caucasus|last=Minns|first=Ellis|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2011|isbn=9781108024877|location=Cambridge|pages=128, 594}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com.ph/books?id=FSRPCAAAQBAJ&pg=PT329&dq=Aspurgiani&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjB5NGi4NPeAhWBa7wKHSGMBG8Q6AEINTAC#v=onepage&q=Aspurgiani&f=false|title=The Geography of Strabo : Volume II (Illustrated)|last=Strabo|date=2014-04-07|publisher=Lulu Press, Inc|isbn=9781312078659|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=The Routledge Companion to Strabo|last=Dueck|first=Daniela|publisher=Routledge|year=2017|isbn=9781317445852|location=London|pages=158}}</ref> An account cited that these tribes were more of a political party or a military colony rather than a tribe, having been founded by a person called [[Tiberius Julius Aspurgus|Aspurgus]], who once was a king of the [[Bosporan Kingdom|Bosporan kingdom]].<ref name=":0" />
==References== *{{SmithDGRG}} *[http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.01.0198%3Abook%3D11%3Achapter%3D2%3Asection%3D11 Strabo's book 11 on-line]

==The Allan Martin Award== This biennial award has been named for [[A. W. Martin]]<ref name="bibliography">{{cite web |title= Bibliography of A. W. Martin’s Writings |publisher= University of Melbourne |url= http://www.mup.unimelb.edu.au/ebooks/0-522-85388-9/WhigView_Biblio.pdf |accessdate= 2007-07-21 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070621192316/http://www.mup.unimelb.edu.au/ebooks/0-522-85388-9/WhigView_Biblio.pdf |archivedate= 21 June 2007 |deadurl= yes |df= dmy-all }}</ref> (1926–2002) and is administered jointly by the [[Australian National University]] and the [[Australian Historical Association]]. The award is to encourage "early career historians" for work relating to Australian History.<ref name="martin">{{cite web|title=The Allan Martin Award |publisher=AHA |url=http://www.theaha.org.au/Allan%20Martin%20Award%20-%20Info&Application%20form_2008.doc |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070804170123/http://www.theaha.org.au/Allan%20Martin%20Award%20-%20Info%26Application%20form_2008.doc |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 August 2007 |accessdate=2007-07-21 |df=dmy }}</ref> Submissions for this award are to be work that is being prepared for publication and can be in any form, e.g. a monograph, a series of academic articles, an exhibition or documentary film, or some mix of these.<ref name = "martin" />
* '''2004''': Maria Nugent for ''Botany Bay: Where Histories Meet'' (Allen & Unwin)<ref>[http://www.theaha.org.au/Allan%20Martin%20Award%20Winner%202004%20-%20Citation.doc Allen Martin 2004 Award citation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070804165305/http://www.theaha.org.au/Allan%20Martin%20Award%20Winner%202004%20-%20Citation.doc |date=4 August 2007 }}</ref> * '''2006''': ''No award made'' * '''2008''': Dr Fred Cahir for ''Black gold: aboriginal peoples and gold in Victoria 1850-1870'' * '''2008''': Highly Commended: Dr Keir Reeves for ''Wild onions: a history of Chinese gold-seekers in the Pearl River Delta region of China and the Central Victorian goldfields. * '''2010''': ''No award made'' <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaha.org.au/awards/martin/winners.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110218174407/http://www.theaha.org.au/awards/martin/winners.htm |archivedate=18 February 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> * '''2012''': Dr Melissa Bellanta, University of Queensland,.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaha.org.au/awards-prizes.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130312070553/http://www.theaha.org.au/awards-prizes.html |archivedate=12 March 2013 |df=dmy }}</ref> * '''2014''': Amanda Kaladelfos for ''Immigration, Violence and Australia Postwar Politics''.<ref name="theaha.org.au">http://www.theaha.org.au/ Retrieved 2014-8-8</ref> * '''2016''': Ruth Morgan for ''Australindia: Australia, India and the Ecologies of Empire, 1788–1901''<ref name="AM previous">{{cite web|title=Allan Martin Award - Previous Winners|url=http://www.theaha.org.au/awards-and-prizes/the-allan-martin-award/allan-martin-award-previous-winners/|website=The Australian Historical Association|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * '''2016''': Highly Commended: Kirstie Close-Barry for ''Intersecting Indigenous Histories: Aboriginal and Pacific Islander Connections in Australia’s Northern Territory''<ref name="AM previous" /> * '''2017''': Benjamin Mountford for ''A Global History of Australian Gold''<ref name="AM previous" /> * '''2017''': Highly Commended: Vannessa Hearman for ''Dealing with the Timorese “Boat People”: Australian and Indonesian Government Responses to the 1995 Arrival in Darwin of the Timorese Asylum Seekers Aboard the Tasi Diak''<ref name="AM previous" />
==Blackwell AHA Prize==
The publishers, Blackwell Publishing Asia, have sponsored a prize for the best postgraduate paper at a Regional Conference.
The AHA information states that the "prize will be judged on two criteria: 1) oral presentation of the paper 2) written version of the conference paper. The written version of the conference paper (not a longer version) is to be submitted at the start of the conference. The winner of the prize will be announced at the close of the conference."<ref name="blackwell">{{cite web|title=Blackwell AHA Prize for the Best Postgraduate Paper at the Regional Conference 2007 |publisher=AHA |url=http://www.theaha.org.au/prizesandawards.htm |accessdate=2007-07-21 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070709215021/http://www.theaha.org.au/prizesandawards.htm |archivedate=9 July 2007 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }}</ref>
* '''2007 Winners''' :: Melissa Bellanta ([[University of Sydney]]) for ''Raiders of the Lost Civilisation'', or, ''Adventure-Romances of the Australian Desert, 1890-1907'', and :: Nell Musgrove ([[University of Melbourne]]) for ''Private Homes, Public Scrutiny: Surveillance of 'the family' in postwar Melbourne''
==WK Hancock Prize==
The WK Hancock Prize is run by [[Australian Historical Association]] (AHA)<ref name = "AHA">{{cite web |title= The Australian Historical Association |publisher= AHA |url= http://www.theaha.org.au/ |accessdate= 2007-07-17| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070717183526/http://www.theaha.org.au/| archivedate= 17 July 2007 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> with the Department of Modern History, [[Macquarie University]]. It was instituted in 1987 in honour of [[Sir (William) Keith Hancock|Sir Keith Hancock]] and his life achievements.
The award is for the first book of history by an Australian scholar and for research using original sources. It is awarded biennially for a first book published in the preceding two years with the award presented at the AHA's National Biennial Conference.
* '''2004 Winners''' :: [[Mary Anne Jebb]] for ''Blood, Sweat and Welfare: a History of White Bosses and Aboriginal Pastoral Workers'' (UWA Press, 2002)<small>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070709215223/http://www.theaha.org.au/HANCOCK%20PRIZE%20CITATION%202004.doc citation]</small> :: [[Warwick Anderson]] for ''The Cultivation of Whiteness: Science, Health and Racial Destiny in Australia'' (Melbourne University Press, 2002)<small>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070709215223/http://www.theaha.org.au/HANCOCK%20PRIZE%20CITATION%202004.doc]</small> ** '''Highly Commended''' :: [[John Connor]] for ''The Australian Frontier Wars: 1788-1838'' ([[University of New South Wales Press]]) :: [[Brigid Hains]] for ''The Ice and the Inland: Mawson, Flynn, and the Myth of the Frontier'' ([[Melbourne University Press]])
* '''2006 Winner''' [[Tony Roberts (history writer)|Tony Roberts]] for ''Frontier Justice: A History of the Gulf Country to 1900'' (UQP, 2005) ** '''Highly Commended''' :: [[Maria Nugent]] for ''Botany Bay: Where Histories Meet'' (Allen & Unwin, 2005) :: [[Sue Taffe]] for ''Black and White Together, FCAATSI 1958-1972'' (UQP, 2005)
* '''2008 Winner''': ::[[Robert Kenny (historian)|Robert Kenny]] for ''The Lamb enters the Dreaming: Nathaniel Pepper and the Ruptured World'' (Scribe Publications, 2007) **'''2008 Highly Commended''' :: [[Tracey Banivanua-Mar]] for ''Violence and Colonial Dialogue: The Australian-Pacific Indentured Labor Trade'' (University of Hawaii Press, 2007)
* '''2010 Winner''': :: Dr [[Natasha Campo]] for ''From Superwomen to Domestic Goddesses: the rise and fall of Feminism'' Peter Lang, 2009 **'''2010 Commendation''' :: Dr [[Clare Corbould]] for ''Becoming African Americans" Black Public Life in Harlem, 1919-1939'' Harvard University Press, 2009<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theaha.org.au/awards/hancock/winners.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-02-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110218174856/http://www.theaha.org.au/awards/hancock/winners.htm |archivedate=18 February 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref>
*'''2012 Joint Winners''' ::[[Frances M Clarke]] for ''War Stories: Suffering and Sacrifice in the Civil War North''
::[[Ian Coller]] for ''Arab France: Islam and the Making of Modern Europe, 1798-1831''
**'''2012 Commendation''' :: [[Michael L. Ondaatje]] for ''Black Conservative Intellectuals in Modern America''<ref>http://www.theaha.org.au/awards-and-prizes/w-k-hancock-prize/w-k-hancock-prize-previous-winners/</ref>
* '''2014 Winner''': ::[[Janet Butler]] for ''Kitty’s War: The Remarkable Wartime Experiences of [[Kit McNaughton]]'' ([[University of Queensland Press]], 2013)
* '''2016 Winner''': ::Adam Clulow for ''The Company and The Shogun: The Dutch Encounter with Tokugawa Japan'' (Columbia University Press, 2014)<ref name="Hancock Previous">{{cite web|title=W H Hancock Prize - Previous Winners|url=http://www.theaha.org.au/awards-and-prizes/w-k-hancock-prize/w-k-hancock-prize-previous-winners/|website=The Australian Historical Association|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> **'''2016 Highly Commended''' :: Ruth Morgan for ''Running Out? Water in Western Australia'' (UWA Publishing, 2015)<ref name="Hancock Previous" /> * '''2018 Winner''':
:: Miranda Johnson for ''The Land Is Our History: Indigeneity, Law, and the Settler State'' (Oxford University Press)<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.booksandpublishing.com.au/articles/2018/07/10/111140/australian-historical-association-2018-awards-announced/|title=Australian Historical Association 2018 awards announced {{!}} Books+Publishing|access-date=2018-09-01|language=en-AU}}</ref>
==The Jill Roe Prize==
The Jill Roe Prize is awarded annually to a postgraduate student for the best unpublished article of historical research. It was inaugurated in 2014 in honour of the late [[Jill Roe]].
* '''2014''': Chris Holdridge for ''The Pageantry of the Anti-Convict Cause: Colonial Loyalism and Settler Celebrations in Tasmania and Cape Colony'' (published in ''History Australia 12, No. 1, April 2015).<ref name="Jill Roe previous">{{cite web|title=Jill Roe Prize - Previous Winners|url=http://www.theaha.org.au/awards-and-prizes/jill-roe-prize/jill-roe-prize-previous-winners/|website=The Australian Historical Association|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * '''2015''': No prize awarded.<ref name="Jill Roe previous" /> * '''2016''': James H. Dunk for ''The Liability of Colonial Madness: Jonathan Burke Hugo in Port Dalrymple, Sydney and Calcutta, 1812.''<ref name="Jill Roe previous" /> * '''2017''': James Findlay for ''Cinematic Landscapes, Dark Tourism and the Ghosts of Port Arthur.''<ref name="Jill Roe previous" />
==The John Barrett Award for Australian Studies== The John Barrett Award for Australian Studies is for the best written article published in the ''Journal of Australian Studies'', in the categories: the best article by a scholar (open) and the best article by a scholar (post-graduate).
John Barrett Award: Open Category * '''2014''': [[Nathan Garvey]] for ‘“Folkalising” Convicts: a “Botany Bay” Ballad and its Cultural Contexts’, JAS, Vol.38 No.1 (March) (2014): 32–51<ref>http://explore.tandfonline.com/content/pgas/jas-john-barrett-award</ref> * '''2014 Highly Commended''': Mark McKenna for ''Tokenism or belated recognition? Welcome to Country and the Emergence of Indigenous Protocol in Australia, 1991–2004'' JAS, Vol.38 No.4 (December) (2014): 476–89 <ref>[http://nasa.org/blog/2015-winners-john-barrett-award/Retrieved 2015-12-13]</ref> * '''2013''': [[Lyndall Ryan]]. 'The Black Line in Van Diemen’s Land (Tasmania), 1830', ''JAS'', 37:1 (2013): 3-18.<ref>[http://inasa.org/blog/announcing-the-winners-of-the-john-barrett-award-for-australian-studies-2013/ Retrieved 2014-8-8]</ref> * '''2012''': [[Zoe Anderson]], 'Borders, babies and ‘good refugees’: Australian representations of ‘illegal’ immigration, 1979', ''JAS'', 36:4 (2012): 499-514.<ref name="inasa.org">http://inasa.org/blog/the-annual-john-barrett-prize/ Retrieved 2014-8-8</ref>
John Barrett Award: Postgraduate Category * '''2013''': Not awarded. * '''2012''': [[Jessica Neath]], 'Empty lands: contemporary art approaches to photographing historical trauma in Tasmania', ''JAS'' 36:3 (2012): 309-325.<ref name="inasa.org"/>
==The Kay Daniels Award==
Inaugurated in 2004, this award is named for [[Kay Daniels]] (1941–2001),<ref name="obit">{{cite web|title=Kay Daniels, 1941-2001 |publisher=AHA |url=http://www.theaha.org.au/Kay%20Daniel%20Obit%20AHS.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20030428210615/http://www.theaha.org.au/Kay%20Daniel%20Obit%20AHS.htm |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 April 2003 |accessdate=2007-07-21 |df=dmy }}</ref> historian and public servant,<ref name="daniels">{{cite web|title=The Kay Daniels Inaugural Award: 2004 |publisher=AHA |url=http://www.theaha.org.au/Kay%20Daniels%20Award_2008.doc |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070804170052/http://www.theaha.org.au/Kay%20Daniels%20Award_2008.doc |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2007-08-04 |accessdate=2007-07-21 |df=dmy }}</ref> and recognises her interest in colonial and heritage history.
The biennial award will be administered by The [[Australian Historical Association]].<ref name = "daniels" />
* '''2004''': Lucy Frost and Hamish Maxwell-Stuart (eds) for ''Chain Letters: Narrating Convict Lives'' ([[Melbourne University Press]]) * '''2006''': Trudy Mae Cowley for ''A Drift of 'Derwent Ducks: Lives of the 200 Female Irish Convicts Transported on the Australasia from Dublin to Hobart in 1849'' (Research Tasmania, Hobart, 2005)<small>[https://web.archive.org/web/20070804165714/http://www.theaha.org.au/2006%20Kay%20Daniels%20Citation2.rtf Review]</small> * '''2008''': Kirsty Reid for ''Gender, Crime and Empire: Convicts, Settlers and the State in Early Colonial Australia'' * '''2010''': Dr Hamish Maxwell-Stuart for ''Closing Hell's Gates: the Death of a Convict Station'' (Allen & Unwin 2008) * '''2014''': Kristyn Harman for ''Aboriginal Convicts: Australian, Khoisan and Maori Exiles'',(UNSW Press 2012) <ref name="theaha.org.au"/> * '''2016''': Sue Castrique for ''Under the Colony’s Eye: Gentlemen and Convicts on Cockatoo Island 1839–1869'' (Anchor Books Australia, 2014)<ref>{{cite web|title=Kay Daniels Award - Previous Winners|url=http://www.theaha.org.au/awards-and-prizes/kay-daniels-award/kay-daniels-award-previous-winners/|website=The Australian Historical Association|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref> * '''2018''': Joan Kavanagh and Dianne Snowden for ''Van Diemen’s Women: A History of Transportation to Tasmania'' (The History Press Ltd).<ref name=":0" />
==The Serle Award==
The Serle Award was first presented in 2002. The award was established through the generosity of Mrs Jessie Serle for the historian [[Geoffrey Serle]] (1922–1998).<ref name="Serle Award">{{cite web|title=The Serle Award |publisher=AHA |url=http://www.theaha.org.au/Serle%20Award%20Info&application%20form_2008.doc |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070804165921/http://www.theaha.org.au/Serle%20Award%20Info%26application%20form_2008.doc |dead-url=yes |archive-date=4 August 2007 |accessdate=2007-07-21 |df=dmy }}</ref>
The Serle Award is for the best thesis by an "early career researcher" and will be payable on receipt of publisher’s proofs, which must be within twelve months of notification of the award.
The biennial award will be administered by [[The Australian Historical Association]].<ref name = "Serle Award" />
* '''2005 Winner''': Bartolo Ziino for ''A distant grief: Australians, War Graves and the Great War'' ([[University of Melbourne]], PhD 2003) :: '''Commendation''': Catherine Mary Gilchrist for ''Male Convict Sexuality in the Penal Colonies of Australia 1820-1850'' ([[University of Sydney]], PhD 2004)
* '''2006 Winner''': Jessie Mitchell for ''Flesh, Dreams and Spirit: Life on Aboriginal Mission Stations 1825-1850 A History of Cross-Cultural Connections'' ([[Australian National University|ANU]] PhD thesis, 2005) * '''2008''': Marina Larsson for ''The Burdens of Sacrifice: War Disability in Australian Families, 1914-1939'' (Latrobe University PhD 2006) ::'''Highly Commended''' :****:Olwen Valda Pryke for ''Australia House: Representing Australia in Great Britain 1901-1939'' (University of Sydney PhD 2006) :****: Robert Bollard for ''The Active Chorus: The Mass Strike of 1917 in Eastern Australia'' (Victoria University PhD 2007) * '''2010''': Dr Simon Sleight for ''The Territories of Youth: Young People and Public Space in Melbourne c1870-1901'' (Monash University PhD 2008) ::'''Commendations''' :****: Dr Malcolm Allbrook for ''Imperial Family: the Prinseps, Empire and Colonial Government in India and Australia'' (Griffith University PhD 2008) :****:Dr Clare McLisky for "Settlers on a Mission" Faith, Power and Subjectivity in the Lives of Danial and Janet Matthews'' (University of Melbourne PhD 2008) * '''2014''': Carolyn Holbrook for ''The Great War in the Australian Imagination Since 1915''.<ref name="theaha.org.au"/> * '''2016''': Laura Rademaker for ''Language and the Mission: Talking and Translating on Groote Eylandt, 1943–1973''.<ref>{{cite web|title=Serle Award - Previous Winners|url=http://www.theaha.org.au/awards-and-prizes/serle-award/serle-award-previous-winners/|website=The Australian Historical Association|accessdate=8 September 2017}}</ref>

revision.text:
[[File:Church of Christ icon.jpg|thumb|250px|[[Medieval]] Russian [[icon]] depicting the ''[[Life of Christ in art|Life of Christ]]'']] A '''chronology of Jesus''' aims to establish a [[timeline]] for the events of the life of [[Jesus]]. Scholars have correlated [[Jewish]] and [[Greco-Roman]] documents and astronomical calendars with the [[New Testament]] accounts to estimate dates for the major events in Jesus's life. Two main approaches have been used to estimate the year of the [[Nativity of Jesus|birth of Jesus]]: one based on the accounts in the [[Gospels]] of his birth with reference to [[Herod the Great|King Herod's]] reign, and the other by subtracting his stated age of "about 30 years" when he began preaching. Most scholars, on this basis, assume a date of birth between 6 and 4 BC.[[John P. Meier]] (1991). ''A Marginal Jew: Rethinking the Historical Jesus'', v. 1; [[John P. Meier#A Marginal Jew: Rethinking the Historical Jesus|''The Roots of the Problem and the Person'']], ch. 11, ... "A Chronology of Jesus Life," pp. 373–433. [[Anchor Bible Series|Anchor Bible Reference Library]].{{Cite journal | first = | last = [[James Dunn (theologian)|Dunn, James D.G.]] | title = Jesus Remembered | publisher = Eerdmans Publishing | year = 2003 | page = 324}}[[D. A. Carson]], [[Douglas J. Moo]] & [[Leon Morris]]. (1992). ''An Introduction to the New Testament'', 54, 56. Grand Rapids, MI: Zondervan Publishing House.[[Michael Grant (author)|Michael Grant]]. (1977). ''Jesus: An Historian's Review of the Gospels'', p. 71. Scribner's.[[Ben Witherington III]]. (1998). "Primary Sources". ''Christian History'', ''17'' (3), 12–20. Three details have been used to estimate the year when [[Ministry of Jesus|Jesus began preaching]]: a mention of his age of "about 30 years" during "the fifteenth year" of the reign of [[Tiberius Caesar]], another relating to the date of the building of the [[Herod's Temple|Temple in Jerusalem]], and yet another concerning the [[death of John the Baptist]].Eerdman Publishing. (2000). ''Eerdman’s Dictionary of the Bible'', page 249. Amsterdam University Press. {{ISBN|90-5356-503-5}}.Craig A. Evans. (2003). ''The Bible Knowledge Background Commentary: Matthew-Luke'', volume 1, pages 67-69 {{ISBN|0-7814-3868-3}}.[[Paul L. Maier]]. "The Date of the Nativity and Chronology of Jesus" [In] Jerry Vardaman, Edwin M. Yamauchi. (1989). ''Chronos, kairos, Christos: nativity and chronological studies'', pages 113-129. {{ISBN|0-931464-50-1}}.Craig Evans. (2006). Josephus on John the Baptist [In] Amy-Jill Levine et al.[Eds]. (2006). ''The Historical Jesus in Context'', pages 55-58. Princeton University Press. {{ISBN|978-0-691-00992-6}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=HIp_0N3uPPcC&pg=PA56&dq=%22Mark+6:17%22+death+baptist+josephus&hl=en&ei=hTubTpKeHcX54QTn1YHBAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=%22Mark%206%3A17%22%20death%20baptist%20josephus&f=false]Florence Morgan Gillman. (2003). ''Herodias: at home in that fox's den'', pages 25-30. {{ISBN|0-8146-5108-9}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=rFRFe8QdO1gC&pg=PA26&dq=herodias+herod+antipas&hl=en&ei=fECbTq31JvDc4QT8ubiZBA&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=herodias%20herod%20antipas&f=false]Geoffrey W. Bromiley. (1982). ''International Standard Bible Encyclopedia'', volume E-J, pages 694-695. {{ISBN|0-8028-3782-4}}. [https://books.google.com/books?id=yklDk6Vv0l4C&pg=PA695&dq=herodias+john+baptist&hl=en&ei=PJacToTRNK-L4gThwKGkCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CC0Q6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=herodias%20john%20baptist&f=false] Hence, scholars estimate that Jesus began preaching and gathering followers around AD 28–29. According to the three [[synoptic gospel]]s Jesus continued preaching for at least one year, and according to [[John the Evangelist]] for three years.''The Riddles of the Fourth Gospel: An Introduction to John'' by Paul N. Anderson 2011 {{ISBN|0-8006-0427-X}} page 200''Herod the Great'' by Jerry Knoblet 2005 {{ISBN|0-7618-3087-1}} pages 183–184J. Dwight Pentecost. (1981) ''The Words and Works of Jesus Christ: A Study of the Life of Christ'', pages 577–578. Zondervan. Five methods have been used to estimate the date of the [[crucifixion of Jesus]]. One uses non-Christian sources such as [[Josephus]] and [[Tacitus]].{{cite book |last=Funk |first=Robert W. |author2=[[Jesus Seminar]] |authorlink=Robert W. Funk| title=The acts of Jesus: the search for the authentic deeds of Jesus |year=1998 |publisher=Harper |location=San Francisco}}Paul William Meyer, John T. Carroll. (2004). ''The Word in this world'', page 112. {{ISBN|0-664-22701-5}}. Another works backwards from the historically well-established trial of the [[Apostle Paul]] by the [[Lucius Junius Gallio Annaeanus|Roman proconsul Gallio]] in Corinth in AD 51/52 to estimate the date of [[Conversion of Paul the Apostle|Paul's conversion]]. Both methods result in AD 36 as an upper bound to the crucifixion.Andreas J. Köstenberger, L. Scott Kellum. (2009). ''The Cradle, the Cross, and the Crown: An Introduction to the New Testament'', pages 77-79. {{ISBN|978-0-8054-4365-3}}.[[Rainer Riesner]]. (1997). ''Paul's early period: chronology, mission strategy, theology'' pages 19-27. {{ISBN|978-0-8028-4166-7}}. Page 27 has a table of various scholarly estimates. Thus, scholars generally agree that Jesus was [[crucified]] between AD 30 and AD 36.''Jesus & the Rise of Early Christianity: A History of New Testament Times'' by Paul Barnett 2002 {{ISBN|0-8308-2699-8}} pages 19-21''The Cradle, the Cross, and the Crown: An Introduction to the New Testament'' by [[Andreas J. Köstenberger]], L. Scott Kellum 2009 {{ISBN|978-0-8054-4365-3}} page 114{{Cite journal | last = Sanders | year = 1993 | pages = 11, 249|title=The Historical Figure of Jesus| postscript = . }} [[Isaac Newton]]'s astronomical method calculates those ancient Passovers (always defined by a full moon) which are preceded by a Friday, as specified by all four Gospels; this leaves two potential crucifixion dates, 7 April AD 30 and 3 April AD 33.Colin J. Humphreys & W. G. Waddington. (1985). The Date of the Crucifixion. ''Journal of the American Scientific Affiliation'', ''37''. (March 1985). [http://www.asa3.org/aSA/PSCF/1985/JASA3-85Humphreys.html] In the [[lunar eclipse]] method, the Apostle Peter's statement that the moon turned to blood at the crucifixion ([[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Acts#2:14|Acts of the Apostles 2:14-21]]) is taken to refer to the lunar eclipse of 3 April AD 33; although astronomers are discussing whether the eclipse was visible as far west as Jerusalem. Recent astronomical research uses the contrast between the synoptic date of Jesus' last Passover on the one hand with John's date of the subsequent "Jewish Passover" on the other hand, to propose Jesus' Last Supper to have been on Wednesday, 1 April AD 33 and the crucifixion on Friday 3 April AD 33. ==Context and overview== [[File:Josephus Antiquitates Iudaice.jpg|thumb|left|180px|''[[Antiquities of the Jews]]'' by [[Flavius Josephus|Josephus]], a source for the chronology of Jesus.]]The Christian gospels do not claim to provide an exhaustive list of the events in the life of Jesus{{cite book |authorlink= Raymond E. Brown |last=Brown |first=Raymond E. |year=1994 |location=New York |publisher=Doubleday, Anchor Bible Reference Library |page=964|isbn=978-0-385-19397-9 |title=The Death of the Messiah: from Gethsemane to the Grave: A Commentary on the Passion Narratives in the Four Gospels}}''[[Christology: A Biblical, Historical, and Systematic Study of Jesus]]'' by [[Gerald O'Collins]] 2009 {{ISBN|0-19-955787-X}} pages 1-3''Jesus as a Figure in History: How Modern Historians View the Man from Galilee'' by Mark Allan Powell 1998 {{ISBN|0-664-25703-8}} pages 168-173 They were written as theological documents in the context of [[early Christianity]] rather than historical chronicles, and their authors showed little interest in an absolute chronology of Jesus or in synchronizing the episodes of his life with the secular history of the age.[[Karl Rahner]]. (2004). ''Encyclopedia of theology: a concise Sacramentum mundi'', pages 730-731. {{ISBN|0-86012-006-6}}''Interpreting Gospel Narratives: Scenes, People, and Theology'' by Timothy Wiarda 2010 {{ISBN|0-8054-4843-8}} pages 75-78Paula Fredriksen. (1999). ''Jesus of Nazareth, King of the Jews'', pages=6–7, 105–10, 232–34, 266. [[Alfred A. Knopf]] Publishers. One indication that the gospels are theological documents rather than historical chronicles is that they devote about one-third of their text to just seven days, namely the last week of the life of Jesus in Jerusalem, also known as [[Passion (Christianity)|the Passion of Christ]].''Matthew'' by David L. Turner 2008 {{ISBN|0-8010-2684-9}} page 613 Nevertheless, the gospels provide some details regarding events which can be clearly dated, so one can establish date ranges regarding major events in Jesus' life by comparison with independent sources.{{Cite journal | title = The Historical Figure of Jesus | last = Sanders | first = EP | publisher = Penguin Books | place = London | year = 1995 | page = 3}} A number of historical non-Christian documents, such as Jewish and [[Greco-Roman]] sources, have been used in historical analyses of the chronology of Jesus.''Jesus and the Gospels: An Introduction and Survey'' by Craig L. Blomberg 2009 {{ISBN|0-8054-4482-3}} pages 431-436 Virtually all modern historians agree that Jesus existed, and regard [[Baptism of Jesus|his baptism]] and [[Crucifixion of Jesus|his crucifixion]] as historical events, and assume that approximate ranges for these events can be estimated.In a 2011 review of the state of modern scholarship, [[Bart Ehrman]] wrote: "He certainly existed, as virtually every competent scholar of antiquity, Christian or non-Christian, agrees" B. Ehrman, 2011 ''Forged : writing in the name of God'' {{ISBN|978-0-06-207863-6}}. page 285{{Cite journal | quote = There is almost universal agreement that Jesus lived | first = Bernard L | last = Ramm | title = An Evangelical Christology: Ecumenic and Historic | publisher = Regent College Publishing | year = 1993 | page = 19}}{{Cite journal | quote = some judgements are so probable as to be certain; for example, Jesus really existed | first = Marcus | last = Borg| title = The Meaning of Jesus: Two Visions (Ch. 16, A Vision of the Christian Life) | publisher = HarperCollins | year = 1999 | page = 236}} Using these methods, most scholars assume a date of birth between 6 and 4 BC, and that Jesus' preaching began around AD 27–29 and lasted one to three years. They calculate the death of Jesus as having taken place between AD 30 and 36. == Year of Jesus' birth == {{See also|Nativity of Jesus|Date of birth of Jesus}} The date of birth of Jesus of Nazareth is not stated in the gospels or in any secular text, but most scholars assume a date of birth between 6 BC and 4 BC, but nobody knows the exact date. Two main methods have been used to estimate the year of the [[Nativity of Jesus|birth of Jesus]]: one based on the accounts of his birth in the gospels with reference to [[Herod the Great|King Herod's]] reign, and another based on subtracting his stated age of "about 30 years" from the time when he began preaching ([[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#3:23|Luke 3:23]]) in "the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar" ([[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#3:1|Luke 3:1-2]]): the two methods indicate a date of birth before Herod's death in 4 BC, and a date of birth around 2 BC, respectively. *''New Testament History'' by Richard L. Niswonger 1992 {{ISBN|0-310-31201-9}} pages 121-124 *''Encyclopedia of theology: a concise Sacramentum mundi'' by [[Karl Rahner]] 2004 {{ISBN|0-86012-006-6}} page 731 *Nikos Kokkinos, 1998, in ''Chronos, kairos, Christos 2'' by Ray Summers, Jerry Vardaman {{ISBN|0-86554-582-0}} pages 121-126 *Murray, Alexander, [http://www.historytoday.com/alexander-murray/medieval-christmas "Medieval Christmas"], ''History Today'', December 1986, '''36''' (12), pp. 31 – 39. *''The Cradle, the Cross, and the Crown: An Introduction to the New Testament'' by [[Andreas J. Köstenberger]], L. Niswonger 1992 {{ISBN|0-310-31201-9}} pages 121-124 ===Subtracting Jesus' age of "about 30 years" when preaching=== Another approach to estimating Jesus' year of birth is based on the statement in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#3:23|Luke 3:23]] that he was "about 30 years of age" when starting his ministry.''The Cradle, the Cross, and the Crown: An Introduction to the New Testament'' by [[Andreas J. Köstenberger]], L. Scott Kellum 2009 {{ISBN|978-0-8054-4365-3}} page 114 Jesus began to preach after being baptised by [[John the Baptist]], and based on Luke’s gospel John only began baptising people in "the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar" ([[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#3:1|Luke 3:1–2]]), which scholars estimate to have been in AD 28–29.''Eerdmans Dictionary of the Bible'' 2000 Amsterdam University Press {{ISBN|90-5356-503-5}} page 249''The Bible Knowledge Background Commentary: Matthew-Luke, Volume 1'' by Craig A. Evans 2003 {{ISBN|0-7814-3868-3}} pages 67–69{{Cite book|title = Chronological Aspects of the Life of Christ | last = Hoehner| first = Harold W | authorlink = Harold Hoehner|year= 1978|publisher=Zondervan |isbn= 0-310-26211-9|pages= 29–37| url = https://books.google.com/?id=6z-NcR7fVSIC&dq=CHronological+Aspects+of+the+Life+of+Christ}} Subtracting 30 years, it appears that Jesus was born in 1-2 BC. However, if the phrase "about 30" is interpreted to mean 32 years old, this could fit a date of birth just within the reign of Herod, who died in 4 BC.''Christianity and the Roman Empire: background texts'' by Ralph Martin Novak 2001 {{ISBN|1-56338-347-0}} pages 302–303 This date is independently confirmed by John's reference in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#2:20|John 2:20]] to the Temple being in its 46th year of construction during Passover when Jesus began his ministry, which corresponds to around 28–29 AD according to scholarly estimates.Jack V. Scarola, "A Chronology of the nativity Era" in ''Chronos, kairos, Christos 2'' by Ray Summers, Jerry Vardaman 1998 {{ISBN|0-86554-582-0}} pages 61–81 ===Other approaches=== The Gospel of John 8:57 mentions in passing an upper limit of 50 for Jesus' age when preaching: ''Then the Jews said to Him: You are not even fifty years old, and you claim to have seen Abraham?'' Fifty years is a round number which emphasises the discrepancy to Jesus's claim he had existed before Abraham, that is, for more than a thousand years.[[Colin Humphreys]], ''The Mystery of the Last Supper'' Cambridge University Press 2011 {{ISBN|978-0-521-73200-0}}, page 72 Some commentators have attempted to establish the date of birth by identifying the [[Star of Bethlehem]] with some known astronomical or astrological phenomenon. For example, astronomer Michael Molnar proposed 17 April 6 BC as the likely date of the Nativity, since that date corresponded to the [[heliacal rising]] and lunar [[occultation]] of [[Jupiter]], while it was [[Apparent retrograde motion#Apparent motion|momentarily stationary]] in the [[Aries (constellation)|constellation of Aries]]. According to Molnar, to knowledgeable astrologers of this time, this highly unusual combination of events would have indicated that a regal personage would be (or had been) born in Judea. Michael R. Molnar, "The Star of Bethlehem: The Legacy of the Magi," Rutgers University Press, 1999. Other research points to a 1991 report from the Royal Astronomical Society, which mentions that Chinese astronomers noted a "comet" that lasted 70 days in the Capricorn region of the sky, in March of 5 BC. Authors Dugard and O'Reilly consider this event as the likely Star of Bethlehem. O'Reilly, Bill, and Dugard, Martin, "Killing Jesus: A History," Henry Holt and Company, 2013, {{ISBN|0805098542}}, page 15. However, there are many possible phenomena and none seems to match the Gospel account exactly.Raymond E. Brown, ''101 Questions and Answers on the Bible'', Paulist Press (2003), page 79. ==Years of preaching== ===Reign of Tiberius and the Gospel of Luke=== [[File:Sapsaphas Madaba.jpg|thumb|Part of the [[Madaba Map]] showing [[Bethabara]] (Βέθαβαρά), calling it the place where John baptised]] One method for the estimation of the date of the beginning of the [[ministry of Jesus]] is based on the Gospel of Luke's specific statement in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Luke#3:1|Luke 3:1-2]] about the ministry of [[John the Baptist]] which preceded that of Jesus:
Now in the fifteenth year of the reign of Tiberius Caesar, Pontius Pilate being governor of Judaea, and Herod being tetrarch of Galilee, and his brother Philip tetrarch of the region of Ituraea and Trachonitis, and Lysanias tetrarch of Abilene, in the highpriesthood of Annas and Caiaphas, the word of God came unto John the son of Zacharias in the wilderness.
The reign of [[Tiberius Caesar]] began on the death of his predecessor [[Augustus Caesar]] in September AD 14, implying that the ministry of John the Baptist began in late AD 28 or early AD 29.Andreas J. Köstenberger, L. Scott Kellum, Charles L Quarles, ''The Cradle, the Cross, and the Crown'' (B&H Publishing, 2009), page 139-140.''Luke 1-5: New Testament Commentary'' by John MacArthur 2009 {{ISBN|0-8024-0871-0}} page 201 Riesner's alternative suggestion is that John the Baptist began his ministry in AD 26 or 27, because Tiberius ruled together with Augustus for two years before becoming the sole ruler. If so, the fifteenth year of Tiberius' reign would be counted from AD 12. Riesner's suggestion is however considered less likely, as all the major Roman historians who calculate the years of Tiberius' rule - namely Tacitus, Suetonius and Cassius Dio - count from AD 14 - the year of Augustus' death. In addition, coin evidence shows that Tiberius started to reign in AD 14.[[Colin Humphreys]], ''The Mystery of the Last Supper'' Cambridge University Press 2011 {{ISBN|978-0-521-73200-0}}, page 64 The New Testament presents [[John the Baptist]] as the precursor to Jesus and the [[Baptism of Jesus]] as marking the beginning of Jesus' ministry.''Jesus and the Gospels: An Introduction and Survey'' by Craig L. Blomberg 2009 {{ISBN|0-8054-4482-3}} page 224-229''Christianity: an introduction'' by Alister E. McGrath 2006 {{ISBN|978-1-4051-0901-7}} pages 16-22 In his sermon in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Acts#10:37|Acts 10:37-38]], delivered in the house of [[Cornelius the Centurion|Cornelius]] the centurion, [[Apostle Peter]] refers to what had happened "throughout all Judaea, beginning from Galilee, after the baptism which John preached" and that Jesus had then gone about "doing good".''Who is Jesus?: an introduction to Christology'' by Thomas P. Rausch 2003 {{ISBN|978-0-8146-5078-3}} page Jesus' baptism account is followed directly by his [[Temptation of Christ|40 day fast and ordeal]]. ===The Temple in Jerusalem and the Gospel of John=== [[File:Jerusalem Modell BW 3.JPG|right|thumb|[[Herod's Temple]], referred to in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#2:13|John 2:13]], as imagined in the [[Holyland Model of Jerusalem]]. It is currently situated adjacent to the [[Shrine of the Book]] exhibit at the [[Israel Museum]], Jerusalem.]] Another method for estimating the start of the ministry of Jesus without reliance on the [[Synoptic gospels]] is to relate the account in the [[Gospel of John]] about the visit of Jesus to [[Herod's Temple]] in Jerusalem with historical data about the construction of the Temple. [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#2:13|John 2:13]] says that Jesus went to the [[Herod's Temple|Temple in Jerusalem]] around the start of his ministry and in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/John#2:20|John 2:20]] Jesus is told: "This temple has been under construction for forty-six years, and will you raise it up in three days?". Herod's Temple in Jerusalem was an extensive and long term construction on the [[Temple Mount]], which was never fully completed even by the time it was destroyed by the Romans in AD 70.''The biblical engineer: how the temple in Jerusalem was built'' by Max Schwartz 2002 {{ISBN|0-88125-710-9}} pages xixx-xx Having built entire cities such as [[Caesarea Maritima]], Herod saw the construction of the Temple as a key, colossal monument.''The Temple of Jerusalem: past, present, and future'' by John M. Lundquist 2007 {{ISBN|0-275-98339-0}} pages101-103 [https://books.google.com/books?id=R9VeCEwbNvsC&pg=PA102&dq=%22john+2:20%22+temple&hl=en&ei=kpydTvvXB-qK4gSg2NHPCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=10&ved=0CFYQ6AEwCTgU#v=onepage&q=%22john%202%3A20%22%20temple&f=false] The dedication of the initial temple (sometimes called the inner Temple) followed a 17 or 18 month construction period, just after the visit of [[Augustus]] to Syria.''The building program of Herod the Great'' by Duane W. Roller 1998 University of California Press {{ISBN|0-520-20934-6}} pages 67-71 [https://books.google.com/books?id=2ZsB1yQOmyEC&pg=PA258&dq=herod+temple+construction&hl=en&ei=DredTu3cIqT64QSitp2nCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=4&ved=0CD8Q6AEwAzge#v=onepage&q=temple%20construction&f=false] [[Josephus]] ([[wikisource:The Antiquities of the Jews/Book XV|Ant 15.11.1]]) states that the temple's reconstruction was started by Herod in the 18th year of his reign.''Encyclopedia of the historical Jesus'' by Craig A. Evans 2008 {{ISBN|0-415-97569-7}} page 115 But there is some uncertainty about how Josephus referred to and computed dates, which event marked the start of Herod's reign, and whether the initial date should refer to the inner Temple, or the subsequent construction. Hence various scholars arrive at slightly different dates for the exact date of the start of the Temple construction, varying by a few years in their final estimation of the date of the Temple visit.''The Cradle, the Cross, and the Crown: An Introduction to the New Testament'' by Andreas J. Köstenberger, L. Scott Kellum 2009 {{ISBN|978-0-8054-4365-3}} pages 140-141 Given that it took 46 years of construction, the best scholarly estimate for when Jesus preached is around the year AD 29.Andreas J. Köstenberger, John (Baker Academic, 2004), page 110.''Jesus in Johannine tradition'' by Robert Tomson Fortna, Tom Thatcher 2001 {{ISBN|978-0-664-22219-2}} page 77 ===Josephus' reference to John the Baptist=== Both the gospels and first-century historian [[Flavius Josephus]], in his work [[Antiquities of the Jews]],''The new complete works of Josephus by Flavius Josephus'', William Whiston, Paul L. Maier {{ISBN|0-8254-2924-2}} refer to [[Herod Antipas]] killing [[John the Baptist]], and to the marriage of Herod and [[Herodias]], establishing two key connections between Josephus and the biblical episodes. Josephus refers to the imprisonment and execution of John the Baptist by Herod Antipas and that Herodias left her husband to marry Herod Antipas, in defiance of Jewish law.[[wikisource:The Antiquities of the Jews/Book XVIII#Chapter 5|Ant 18.5.2-4]] Josephus and the gospels differ, however, on the details and motives, e.g. whether the execution was a consequence of the marriage of Herod Antipas and Herodias (as indicated in [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Matthew#14:4|Matthew 14:4]], [[wikisource:Bible (American Standard)/Mark#6:18|Mark 6:18]]), or a pre-emptive measure by Herod which possibly took place before the marriage to quell a possible uprising based on the remarks of John, as Josephus suggests in [[wikisource:The Antiquities of the Jews/Book XVIII#Chapter 5|Ant 18.5.2]].''Jesus in history, thought, and culture: an encyclopedia, Volume 1'' by James Leslie Houlden 2003 {{ISBN|1-57607-856-6}} pages 508-509 [https://books.google.com/books?id=17kzgBusXZIC&pg=PA508&dq=baptist+josephus+antipas+jesus&hl=en&ei=5kmbTvPYB9TP4QSuzIDjAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=5&sqi=2&ved=0CEAQ6AEwBA#v=onepage&q=baptist%20herodias%20josephus%20antipas%20jesus&f=false]''Women in scripture'' by [[Carol Meyers]], Toni Craven and Ross Shepard Kraemer 2001 {{ISBN|0-8028-4962-8}} pages 92-93 [https://books.google.com/books?id=MFbHT73BxpAC&pg=PA93&dq=herodias+herod&hl=en&ei=FJmcToy0M4abOtTmzIYJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDEQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=herodias%20herod&f=false]''Herod Antipas in Galilee: The Literary and Archaeological Sources'' by Morten H. Jensen 2010 {{ISBN|978-3-16-150362-7}} pages 42-43 [https://books.google.com/books?id=I7fAyl2aG-gC&pg=PA43&dq=herodias+herod&hl=en&ei=FJmcToy0M4abOtTmzIYJ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=3&ved=0CDgQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=herodias%20herod&f=false]''The Emergence of Christianity: Classical Traditions in Contemporary Perspective'' by Cynthia White 2010 {{ISBN|0-8006-9747-2}} page 48 [[File:Baptistry (Castiglione Olona) 003.jpg|thumb|[[John the Baptist|The Baptist]] scolds [[Herod Antipas|Herod]]. Fresco by [[Masolino da Panicale|Masolino]], 1435]] The exact year of the marriage of [[Herod Antipas]] and [[Herodias]] is subject to debate among scholars. While some scholars place the year of the marriage in the range AD 27-31, others have approximated a date as late as AD 35, although such a late date has much less support. In his analysis of Herod's life, [[Harold Hoehner]] estimates that John the Baptist's imprisonment probably occurred around AD 30-31.{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=oO0upEG0g7kC&pg=PA131&dq=herodias+herod+antipas#v=onepage&q=herodias%20herod%20antipas&f=false |title=''Herod Antipas'' by Harold W. Hoehner'' 1983 ISBN 0-310-42251-5 page 131 |publisher=Books.google.com |date=1983-01-28 |accessdate=2012-07-18|isbn=9780310422518 }} The International Standard Bible Encyclopedia estimates the death of the Baptist to have occurred about AD 31-32. Josephus stated ([[wikisource:The Antiquities of the Jews/Book XVIII#Chapter 5|Ant 18.5.2]]) that the AD 36 defeat of Herod Antipas in the conflicts with [[Aretas IV Philopatris|Aretas IV]] of [[Nabatea]] was widely considered by the Jews of the time as misfortune brought about by Herod's unjust execution of John the Baptist.''The relationship between John the Baptist and Jesus of Nazareth'' by Daniel S. Dapaah 2005 {{ISBN|0-7618-3109-6}} page 48 [https://books.google.com/books?id=S0P18O3fGR4C&pg=PA48&dq=baptist+josephus+antipas+jesus&hl=en&ei=5kmbTvPYB9TP4QSuzIDjAg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&sqi=2&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=baptist%20josephus%20antipas%20jesus&f=false] Given that John the Baptist was executed before the defeat of Herod by Aretas, and based on the scholarly estimates for the approximate date of the marriage of Herod Antipas and Herodias, the last part of the ministry of John the Baptist and hence parts of the ministry of Jesus fall within the historical time span of AD 28-35, with the later year 35 having the least support among scholars.''Herod Antipas'' by Harold W.
